TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Does he recall that on 7 April this year, in answer to a question from me, he said that a number of synthetic oil projects, including the Rheinbraun project in the Latrobe Valley, were 'starting to get into place and will aim to be in position by the 1990s and to supplement any decline that there may be in oil'? Was that statement made so as to imply that the Rheinbraun project, amongst others, would fill the gap left by the Rundle shale oil scheme, which had been so enthusiastically talked up by the Minister until April this year? Is it true, as reported in today's Australian Financial Review, that at present oil prices coal-to-oil projects such as the Rheinbraun project would not provide a sufficient rate of return to justify major commercial investment? If this is true, can the Minister now give the Senate his current assessment of the future viability of synthetic oil production in Australia? Does he now agree with the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, which said in May this year that no oil-to-coal or shale-to-oil projects would go ahead in the foreseeable future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in Australia there was unfolded the result of a two-year study by the Federal Republic of Germany and the Comomonwealth Government of Australia in which a number of the great coal chemists and coal enterprises of the world took part. That study was based upon an examination of Victorian brown coal and Queensland and New South Wales bituminous black coal. The papers and the information that were presented will become available; they have been featured in the Press. In fact, what was said was that the Germans, who looked at this both technically and from an economic viewpoint, believed that there could be put in position, commencing from 1984, the building of a plant-a plant functioning in 1989, five years later-which would be commercially viable. That is the viewpoint expressed by those who yesterday put forward their technical and economic facts. It is true that different answers can be arrived at from different bases. One of the main predictions has to be of the trend in Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries oil prices over the years. Nevertheless, the foundation of what was said yesterday was an indication that it was believed that this could be done. It was believed that it should be done with some degree of urgency because of the always perilous situation in the world. One of the companies participating in that survey was, in fact, Rheinbraun.

ANSWER.PARA: These are the factual situations as presented yesterday. Therefore, it is suggested by those with high technical knowledge that coal to oil technology is available, both technically and at a cost feasibility. One needs to look at and examine this with great thoroughness. Our Government and the State governments will be looking at the assumptions made. That presentation was made yesterday. It was stressed that in a world running out of oil it is imperative that, as reasonably quickly as possible, syncrude should be produced either from coal or from shale. Amongst technical people and those who look at economic feasibility there is around the world an immense interest in getting those technologies into place as soon as possible. I can say only that we will examine this with great interest both at a State level and at the Commonwealth level. This was a very important study indeed. I cannot pronounce upon it because the bases will need expert examination. On the other hand, as I said, the report is promising, as to both its findings and its exposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, relates to the preliminary report of the Uranium Advisory Council on its review of the Atomic Energy Act, contained in its annual report tabled in Parliament last week. In particular my question relates to its recommendation which calls for the deletion or changing of sections of Australia's nuclear legislation which restrict civil liberties or which require secrecy. The Minister may recall that I expressed similar concerns during debate in the Senate on the Atomic Energy Amendment Bill in May 1978. Does the Minister agree with the Council's claim that 'public confidence in the industry will not be achieved while it continues to be surrounded by apparent secrecy, such as section IV of the Act appears to require'? If so, I ask: Firstly, what action will be taken by the Government to bring legislation dealing with uranium and the nuclear industry into line with other Commonwealth legislation such as the freedom of information initiatives now being considered by the Parliament? Secondly, when can we expect to see before the Parliament legislation to remove those restrictions on civil liberties and the availability of information which appear inappropriate in the present context of a commercial uranium industry which is conducted for peaceful purposes within the ambit of the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been aware for a very considerable time that the existing Atomic Energy Act is not wholly suitable or relevant to present and future circumstances. Honourable senators will recollect that the Minister for Trade and Resources and I announced in June that the Atomic Energy Act in its present form, since it did not provide the appropriate basis for the development, regulation and control of nuclear activities, should be urgently reviewed and that a new legal base should be established. Consequently a major review of the issues involved is now under way in close consultation with the States and the Northern Territory. I assure honourable senators that the views of the Uranium Advisory Council, expressed in the Council's annual report and referred to by Senator Missen, will be taken into account in the course of that review.

ANSWER.PARA: I expect that legislation will be developed as rapidly as possible, as appropriate, following the review and then brought before the Parliament. Nevertheless, this is a complex and highly technical undertaking and involves very considerable discussions with the States. The Government is conscious of the need for priority to be given to these matters. Clearly it is inappropriate for me to make specific commitments until the Government has received a report concerning the aspects which are under review. I will keep in mind Senator Missen's views, including the comments on freedom of information, and the specific comment made by the Uranium Advisory Council.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry advise whether the beef moguls of the United States of America and Japan, through their recent actions in cutting back Australian beef imports but at the same time lifting the imports of high quality beef between the United States and Japan, are endeavouring to protect their own high consumer priced beef at the expense of the Australian producer, who has supplied the bulk of the much lower priced beef to a considerable percentage of the population of those two nations? Is it possible to vary the export and abattoir regulations in Australia, particularly in areas such as the Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australia, to encourage greater sales and the development of new overseas markets, including South East Asia in particular? With the considerable drop in Australia's beef population, can it be expected that Australia in the near future will be less dependent on the present American and Japanese markets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has raised questions about the level of beef quotas in Japan. Decisions with respect to that are made, of course, by the Japanese Government. They take into account the domestic supply and demand situation for meats in that country. The beef and pork markets in Japan are regulated by price stabilisation schemes which set both maximum and minimum prices prior to the commencement of each year, in April. These prices play an important part in determining the level of retail prices in Japan. If I may use the honourable senator's expression 'beef moguls', my advice is that the United States beef moguls are not involved in the decisions which are taken by the Japanese Government in this area. However, the United States, as part of its overall efforts to increase exports to Japan, has been placing emphasis on exports of its beef to that country. These are drawn mainly from lot fed cattle, which is, of course, a very different sort of beef from that mainly exported by Australia. As to the United States market, the proposed restrictions to which Senator Kilgariff refers relate to health and not quantitative measures. Amendments have been proposed which, if implemented, could have serious implications for exporting countries' ability to supply beef to the United States. Currently a conference of House of Representatives and Senate members in Washington is examining the amendments, and the United States Administration, Australia and other suppliers to the United States are seeking changes which will reduce the impact of the proposed measures.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kilgariff also asked about varying the regulations to encourage greater sales in other markets. There is in this country a uniform standard for export inspection. Overseas markets are continually upgrading their standards, and it would not be prudent to reduce Australian standards in this area. Markets in South East Asia have taken increased quantities from Australia this year. For the nine months to September, meat exports to Malaysia increased by 10 per cent, to Singapore by 20 per cent, to the Philippines by 59 per cent, to Taiwan by 65 per cent and to Korea by 570 per cent.

The last part of the honourable senator's question related to the drop in Australia's beef population making Australia less dependent on the present American and Japanese markets. It remains a fact that the United States and Japanese markets are the best in terms of price, and that situation is expected to continue into the foreseeable future. Therefore, it is likely that Australian exporters will seek to sell on those markets where the price is best. Indeed, if the fall in beef numbers in this country is to have any influence at all it is, I suspect, likely to influence producers to wish to sell in those markets which give them the highest return.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NUCLEAR WARFARE: STUDY BY INTERNATIONAL INSTITUTE OF STRATEGIC STUDIES

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the determination by the London International Institute of Strategic Studies that Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape are early and extremely vulnerable types of targets in a nuclear war? Is he further aware that the same report states that the United States policy of controlled escalation is not realistic since the destruction of communications facilities would make any attempt to reach a settlement of a nuclear war difficult, if not impossible, thus making total nuclear war the most likely result once the first missile is fired? Further, is he aware of reports that the United States now favours a policy of simultaneous retaliation? In this context, I ask whether he is aware of the following recent incredible statement by the President of the United States, in answer to the apparent contradictions between General Haig, who stated that North Atlantic Treaty Organisation policy now included a nuclear warning shot in Europe, and Secretary of Defence Weinberger, who made a denial on that issue:

QUESTION.PARA: There seems to be some confusion as to whether that is still part of NATO strategy or not, and I've had no answer to that.

In view of Australia's direct involvement, what steps is the Government taking to reduce the appalling risks faced by Australians and, indeed, by the whole world in view of the greatly increased risk of nuclear war that is indicated by some of these reports and the equally frightening nonchalance and confusion exhibited by the people with their hands on the trigger?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the study by the London International Institute of Strategic Studies. I will seek it out and read it. I will then be able to give further information on it. But let me deal with Senator Chipp's question first of all on the assumption that the first statement is as he quoted it. It is a sad fact that all defensive installations or weapons that exist in the world would be targets at the onset of war, and the more significant a defensive installation is the more prime the target would be. There is a tremendous dilemma, and it is this: Nations seek to have installations to ensure peace while realising that there is a risk in that regard. I take it that those who understand the functions of the North West Cape and Pine Gap installations would understand that they are in essence a part of the aim of the free world to maintain peace. Therefore of course there would be a vulnerability of any such installation or any such major weapons around the world. Senator Chipp would not journey along this path. Clearly therefore one does not simply take away one's installations or one's weapons because that would be the road to passive resistance and, therefore, overthrow.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chipp referred to a number of quotations of which I am not aware. I am not aware of the ones that he put in the subsequent parts of his question. Therefore all I can do is to undertake to refer them to my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs to check their substance and to seek from him a report upon them. As to the final part of his question about what Australia is doing, I point out that Australia has taken very vigorous steps, internationally and nationally, to give leadership in nuclear non-proliferation and, indeed, nuclear disarmament. Sadly for this world, there is no such thing as a nuclear free zone. All who understand the physical nature of what is called the cosmic mix know that the whole world is subject to the danger of substantial nuclear explosions anywhere in the world. I draw attention to the evidence that Australia gave before the World Court in terms of the Mururoa Atoll tests. Of course Australia is eager to produce nuclear disarmament in the world but the facts of the matter are, as I have mentioned in the Senate, that one nation, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is increasing its armaments at a rate something like double that of the United States of America. Sadly, that has led to a building up of further armaments by the United States of America. I will bring the substance of the question to the attention of the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the answer that he has given. Can I just get an assurance from him? The extraordinary statement of General Haig that NATO policy now includes a nuclear warning shot in Europe is on record, and it is equally on record that Secretary of Defence Weinberger says that it is not the policy. The amazing statement by the President of the United States, also on the record, is that he has no answer as to which one is right.
—Senator Carrick hasn't got one either.

—Of course he does not have it, and I for one do not blame him for not having it. He cannot be expected to have those answers. All I am asking him to do is to obtain from the relevant department or Minister information as to whether those three statements have been made by those three Americans, each of whom has his hands on the trigger for a nuclear war, and to make an announcement to the Senate before it rises.

—I have undertaken to refer those matters to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and to seek clarification. As I understood this, the various matters arose out of the decision by the Reagan Administration to build a neutron bomb which is another nuclear weapon, a so-called limited nuclear weapon. All nuclear weapons, of course, are to be abhorred. The basis of the American argument, as we understand it, is that in terms of both manpower and armour in conventional weapons the Russians so outnumber the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation forces that Western Europe could be overrun quite easily unless there were a supplement to the armoury of the limited nuclear weapon. I do not propose to put into my mouth words which may not be accurate in terms of the President of the United States of America.
