TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Health to the Commonwealth Isolated Patients Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme, which under certain criteria provides refunds of travel and accommodation expenses for patients who are required to travel often very long distances from their homes to a suitable hospital for treatment. In view of the fact that many of these patients are pensioners or persons living in isolated areas who incur very heavy expenses for repeated trips, will the Federal Government examine a voucher system which would relieve these people of a heavy burden of debt? I further ask: In light of the present Commonwealth arrangements, which are subject to delay, and the fact that large numbers of these patients are experiencing financial difficulties in advancing the money necessary for their fares and accommodation, will the Federal Government respond immediately to the Western Australian Government's very generous offer to advance funds for fares and accommodation to patients in that State on the condition that the patients concerned assign the relevant matching Commonwealth reimbursement to the State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton- Browne is correct when he says that the Isolated Patients Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme has brought benefit to people in non-metropolitan areas of Australia and that it does supply cash support for those people who need to travel for medical care and attention. I think the honourable senator may not have mentioned that Western Australia previously had a scheme operating but that its scheme has now been finished, so that many Western Australians who previously looked to the State for assistance are now looking to the Commonwealth and to the Commonwealth scheme. The main concern which I heard the honourable senator express is about delay in payment-that people who use the scheme may have to wait for some time to be repaid.

ANSWER.PARA: I will certainly make known to the Minister for Health the honourable senator's concern. I will make known the suggestion that a voucher system might be appropriate, although I imagine that this would require some fairly careful attention. In particular, I will draw to my colleague's attention the suggestion by Senator Crichton-Browne that it may be possible to take up the offer of the State Government to advance money on the basis that that is repaid when the Commonwealth makes payment in due course. I think my colleague would want to look at all these matters. He would also want to look at the question of whether there could be some expedition of Commonwealth payments to patients who are using what has been a very successful Fraser Government initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Government noted the spate of assassinations of Croatians in France, Germany, Spain and Italy, numbering about 12, during this year? Has the Government taken any particular action in Australia to guard against similar assassinations of Croatians in this country? Has the Government any information to confirm the strong suspicion that members of the Yugoslav secret police have been behind these assasinations? While I am on this subject, I ask: Will the Government give consideration to protesting to the Yugoslav Government about the recent imprisonment for three and a half years of a 40-year-old Franciscan, Father Jozo Zovko, who was convicted of acts of hostile propaganda for allegedly criticising the communist regime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer to the Minister for Foreign Affairs the matters raised by Senator Harradine relating to assassinations, security and imprisonment. I will see whether early information can be given.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ENERGY RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT AND DEMONSTRATION COUNCIL

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Further to my questions of 28 October and 11 November 1981, can the Minister indicate the cost of the Davy McKee Pty Ltd survey on methanol production, funded by the Department of National Development and Energy on the recommendation of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, which failed to consider any South Australian production sites, and in particular the promising Wakefield coal site? Is it true that there is only one South Australian, out of a total of 48 positions, on NERDDC standing committees and is it also true that there are no South Australian representatives on the Technology of Synthetic Fuels Standing Committee? Is it also a fact that last year South Australia received only 2.5 per cent of the total of $13.5m of NERDDC recommended funding for research into energy projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question, the cost of what is called the Davy McKee study on market and production aspects of the use of methanol as a gasolene extender was $125,000. Competitive tendering was used and that particular tenderer was successful. It is true that South Australia has one representative, out of a total of 47 positions, on the seven NERDDC technical standing committees and there are no South Australian representatives on the Technology of Synthetic Fuels Standing Committee. Representatives are chosen for their personal expertise and not as representatives of particular organisations or States. Fundamentally, the findings made are available to South Australia. Queenslanders do not simply make findings and give them to Queensland. In other words, the abilities of those concerned and their findings are available to the whole of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Last year South Australia received 2.5 per cent of the total value of energy research and development grants, which totalled $18.6m. The grants are based on the merits of individual applications and in accord with a framework of established priorities. They are based on the recommendations of an entirely objective and expert committee-NERDDC. The main concentration of researchers and research establishments is in Victoria and New South Wales but, as I say, the results are available to all States. There is no doubt that South Australia will have available to it all of the information that comes out of NERDDC research.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of the editorial in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald which said that Australian theatre is under threat from the creeping philistinism of the Fraser Government? Can the Minister explain or justify the decline in funding to the Australia Council of 39 per cent since 1974 and, in particular, will the Minister explain why the Fraser Government is prepared to parade itself as a friend of the Australian film industry while cutting off funds to the life blood of that industry, namely, Australian live theatre?

—I did not see the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday, nor did I see the editorial, but certainly I will look it up now that Senator Ryan has brought it to my attention. The points which she makes are clearly incorrect. I think the Australian film industry has gone through a remarkable resurgence. Many of us have enjoyed watching Breaker Morant and other films which have added lustre to the film industry. We are also proud of the scheme which was introduced, endorsed and promoted by this Government in the last two years and which has led to quite a few people now looking to film making who would not otherwise have sought to support film making. I have already taken part in a debate on a matter of public importance with Senator Ryan in which we have argued the question of funding for the Australia Council and for the arts. I am happy to do so again at any time. The Fraser Government in fact is making a major contribution through a number of agencies to the arts generally in Australia. The Government considers the area to be important and believes the Australian people would endorse the support it is giving to the arts.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. What percentage of the population was not covered by private health insurance or equivalent Government assistance at 30 October 1981; that is, the last day on which the waiving of the normal waiting period applied?

—Such figures as are available are only preliminary. However, there is some information showing that most Australians are covered; either they are members of registered health insurance funds or are in receipt of equivalent Commonwealth Government assistance. I am advised that for medical cover the figure for people who have basic private insurance, who are pensioners, who hold health care cards or who are in receipt of repatriation or defence care is a little under 89 per cent. The equivalent figure for hospital cover is about 93 per cent. I am advised that there is approximately another 2 per cent of people who cannot yet be accounted for in terms of figures available and that may well take the figures higher. But the figures available do not take into account two other matters. The first of these is that in Queensland a number of people are able to take account of arrangements for free hospital care which operate in that State. It is thought that many people in Queensland are covered under that scheme. Of course, a number of people have taken out cover through non-registered general insurance arrangements. It is thought that adding up all those types of cover it is very likely that the great majority of Australians-in fact almost all-have some kind of cover. We are looking forward to getting more final figures at a later date and I will be happy to make those available to the honourable senator.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that officers of his Department who are actually physically writing counter cheques to assist beneficiaries on an emergency basis are being told to stop writing the cheques and to do overpayments and that when they refuse that order because those cheques are to get income to needy families they are then stood down? Is he further aware that most people stood down are officers from the unemployment and sickness benefits sections and not from the pensions sections, as a result of the selective application of the stand-down orders? Are these particularly confrontationist and selective orders which make departmental discipline a higher priority than the welfare of destitute clients the result of ministerial direction or departmental direction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The administration of my Department is, under the Social Services Act, in the hands of the Director-General and his officers. I have no reason to believe other than that they administer the Act in the best interests of the people they are seeking to serve. Their difficulty in dealing with the sort of situation with which they are faced is borne out by the 'Social Security Bulletin' which has been produced by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association in recent days and which tells public servants how they ought to behave in a stand-down circumstance in a way which is designed to obstruct and to make difficult the carrying out of those duties. I would like to refer to the paper issued under the heading 'Social Security Bulletin' and over the signature of one David Bunn, Branch Secretary, which gives some very useful advice to public servants on how they should be behaving! 'Never refuse a direction', it says. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Agree, if pushed, to perform the instruction. Query deadlines, priorities, and other urgent tasks. Engage the supervisor in discussion about whether it is in the interests of the office, the clients, the Government to perform this task. Never talk about bans. Give verbal agreement to the task-but make it hard to get.
The document gives some other beaut advice as to how people should be serving the public! It says:

If you know that management is coming to give a specific direction, you may feel the need to visit the toilet, or go home early, (initially stand-downs will probably occur late in the day), become engaged in heated conversation over the phone, etc.

With that sort of advice being offered by the union to the public servants who are supposedly working in my Department I can say only that I feel great sympathy for those people who are charged with the duty of carrying out their responsibilities and who are doing so to the best of their ability. I would not support any suggestion of victimisation or behaviour which was not proper. If there are any particular cases which members of the Opposition or any other people wish to draw to my attention the matters raised will be carefully examined by me and by senior officers of my Department. The fact is that the work which is required to be done by my Department in the interests of the pensioners and beneficiaries, in the interests of the unemployed, in the interests of the sick and in the interests of the aged is made more difficult by irresponsible trade union action of which this bulletin represents a very poor example.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. It was an interesting speech by the Minister but it hardly referred to the question. I asked the Minister whether it is a fact that officers of his Department are instructing people on counters to stop writing cheques in emergency situations and to do other things such as check overpayments and that when they refuse they are stood down. Is this selective application of the law an instruction of the Minister or the Department? Is it a fact that the people who are stood down are generally from the unemployment benefits and sickness benefits sections and not from the pensions sections, and that this happens as a result of selective instructions from the Minister or the Department? Perhaps if he has cooled down a bit he will be able to answer the question.

—I made it quite clear in my answer that I have given and I would give no instruction for the selective application of these rules or any other rules. I made that quite clear. I said also that if instead of vague and general allegations the Opposition wishes to raise particular cases for consideration they will be given consideration. I think it would be useful if the Opposition declared its position in these matters and indicated whether it supports the idea that public servants, who are paid by the taxpayer, are entitled to refuse to do the work for which they are employed, to the detriment of pensioners and beneficiaries in this country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED PETROCHEMICAL DEVELOPMENT AT STONY POINT

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to a report in Saturday's Adelaide Advertiser concerning comments attributed to the Whyalla Action Group about the proposed petrochemical development at Stony Point in South Australia. Is he aware that the Action Group claimed that the draft environmental impact statement on Stony Point is a total farce? Will the Minister inform the Senate whether environmental impact statements must cover certain criteria and meet certain standards? Is the Minister satisfied that the statement relating to Stony Point conforms to these standards and is an accurate document? Will the Minister inform the Senate also whether approaches to the Commonwealth Government concerning the leasing of Commonwealth Crown land in the Stony Point area for the purpose of constructing a petrochemical complex? If so, which companies are involved? Does the Minister recognise the importance of this development not only to South Australia in particular but also to Australia generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot think of anything that is more significant to South Australia and indeed to Australia generally than the construction of the pipeline from the Cooper Basin to Whyalla, a pipeline which will be finished by the end of next year or early 1983, a pipeline which basically normally would carry something like 40,000 barrels of liquids a day and under pressure 80,000 barrels of liquids a day-an enormous supplement to Bass Strait. Therefore, as to the latter part of the question, the Government regards it as having a very high priority.

ANSWER.PARA: The environmental impact statement prepared for the Cooper Basin liquids project has been examined by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. The responsible Minister has advised me that sufficient information has been presented in the final environmental impact statement with respect to the port and terminal facilities at Stony Point to enable an adequate assessment of the proposal to be made. Under the administrative procedures of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act the environmental impact statement must cover a number of specific items and an assessment must be made as to whether they fall into acceptable guidelines. The Minister has advised that the object of the Act has been met and complied with in relation to the making of decisions by or on behalf of the Government on the proposal for the development of oil and gas deposits in the Cooper Basin, including the extraction, transportation and treatment of oil and gas from these deposits. In addition, the State may specify particular pollution standards which have to be met. At this moment I do not have information in respect of that part of the question which referred to leasing Crown land in the Stony Point area. I will seek out that information for Senator Jessop and let him have it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns the not inconsiderable confusion and worry which is evident in some sections of the community regarding the future of the Office of Child Care. Can the Minister say whether it is true that the Office of Child Care is to be incorporated with the aged and disabled into a subsidies division within the Department of Social Security? If it is true, will the Minister give an assurance that children's services will be accorded equal priority with that accorded the aged and disabled within that subsidies division?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Usually people are pretty ready to pass on to me their areas of confusion and worry. I have not had too much communication on the point raised by the honourable senator. I may have had some, but I have not seen any representations about that matter, so it is not a matter on which I am able to give the honourable senator a final and definitive reply. The Government did, as part of its Review of Commonwealth Functions, seek a review of the Social Welfare Division of the Department of Social Security. That review was to be carried out by the Public Service Board. I understand that such a review has been carried out and that it is complete, although I have not seen the report on it. I understand also that the Director-General of the Department sought a widening of that review, but I have no details or particulars on that. It may pick up the Office of Child Care and other sections, including the subsidies section, of the Department but I have had no formal communication on that. I have an understanding, which I think flows from casual conversation, that there was a widening of the review beyond the Social Welfare Division.

ANSWER.PARA: No rearrangements of the Department would be made without their first being brought to the attention of the Government, so there is no prospect of that occurring without my first having seen what is to occur and having passed judgment on it. However, whatever administrative rearrangements are made within the Department, they would not be aimed at reducing the significance which is to be given to either the child care functions of my Department or its concern for the aged, the disabled and the handicapped. It may be that some administrative rearrangement would be sensible, but that is a matter on which I reserve judgment at this stage. However, I can assure the Senate that no rearrangement is in mind which would reduce the emphasis which the Government would wish to place on the child care functions of the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Was the 1981 Wool Industry Conference, held in Melbourne last week, told that there would be a substantial increase in charges for wool testing when the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority, as proposed by the so-called razor gang, is completed? Did Mr Des O'Connell, the Australian Wool Council's representative on the board of the Wool Testing Authority, estimate that the increase in charges to wool growers would range between 20 per cent and 40 per cent? Does the Government refute these estimates? Why is the Government proceeding with the sale in the face of opposition from all sections of the wool industry and with no prospect of raising the Authority's efficiency or of lowering its costs to the customer?

—It is some time since I have spoken with the Minister for Primary Industry or received any information from him on this matter. I will seek to obtain a reply to those questions from the Minister as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. The Minister may recall that I tabled the one hundred and eighty-ninth report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on airport fire tenders in this chamber on 17 October and drew his attention to the regrettable mismanagement of the Department of Transport, causing considerable waste of public money. Given that the original contractor for the 25 ultra-large fire tenders, the Walter Motor Truck Co. of the United States of America, went into liquidation on 31 October 1980 and an Australian agent now supplies parts and support services for these vehicles to the Department of Transport, I ask: Firstly, what was the reason for the recent overseas visit of two departmental officers to the Walter Motor Trust Co. of Canada? Secondly, is the Walter Motor Trust Co. of Canada managed by some former executives of the former Walter Motor Truck Co. of the United States of America? Thirdly, is or was a former Department of Transport fire services officer, William Charles Harris, in any way associated with the Walter Motor Trust Co. of Canada? Fourthly, who paid the travel and other expenses of the departmental officers' visit to Canada? What was the total cost of the visit? Were the officers concerned the same persons who visited the United States to test the prototype of the Walter 6,800 litre trucks?
—I invite the Minister, if he feels that too much detail is required in the answer, to have the question placed on notice.

—Before I ask the honourable senator to do that, I should like to say that in fact the Minister is studying the report at the present time. Although he has no comments on the matter at the moment, the honourable senator can rest assured that the matters he has raised in general terms within the ambit of his question will be examined in the closest possible detail. I take up your invitation, Mr President, and ask that the question in detail be placed on notice.

—My question is addressed to you, Mr President, and concerns the pouring of concrete ceremony conducted last Thursday on the site of the new Parliament House. My question is prompted by the fact that the compilers of the souvenir program prepared for that ceremony appeared to disregard protocol by listing the other place ahead of the Senate. For the historical record, Mr President, do you know or could you ascertain whether the pouring ceremony was conducted on the Senate side of the new building or on the other side? I did note that the truck used for the ceremony was red, and I assume that this colour was chosen to designate the area of the site rather than the politics of the person who performed the ceremony.

—It would appear that Senator Robertson's perception again has come to the fore. He has taken note of other factors besides the very historic pouring of the first concrete for the new Parliament House. I will take note of the question, Senator Robertson, and give you a response accordingly.

—My question to the Minister for Social Security is about the major fire which this morning destroyed more than one-half of the main labour-intensive industry in Castlemaine, namely, the Castlemaine woollen mills, which employ about 220 people. I ask: Will the Minister make special arrangements for Social Security officers to visit Castlemaine to assist those workers who may lose their jobs as a result of this fire? Will the Minister also seek assistance from his colleague the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs for Commonwealth Employment Service officers to visit the city to assist these people? Finally, can the Minister say whether any special arrangements can be made for assistance to be given to a town such as Castlemaine when it suffers a disaster of this sort?

—I can understand the honourable senator's concern about what occurred this morning at Castlemaine and the effect it will have on the employment of a significant number of people in that town. I am happy to advise that action has already been taken by both the departments to which he referred in his question. Arrangements have already been made for six officers from the Commonwealth Employment Service and three officers from my own Department to visit Castlemaine tomorrow in order to register people for employment, to register them for unemployment benefit, and to accept the various documents that have to be entered into to ensure that people are protected to the best possible extent. Action is being taken to publicise the visit in the local Press and on radio so that the people affected will be aware of the services which are being offered. With respect to what special arrangements can be made, nothing can be done in the immediate term which I would characterise as a special arrangement other than to ensure that the facilities which are open to people who do not have employment are made available to them. I will have my colleague examine the position in Castlemaine to see whether additional action is required to meet the difficulties of that town following the fire this morning.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will the Minister inform the Senate as to the current position in respect of Australia's participation in the Sinai peacekeeping force, which is contingent upon decisions yet to be made by other governments? Does the Australian Government know whether Canada and the United Kingdom are to commit their armed forces to the Sinai? Is Canadian involvement still a prerequisite to Australian involvement?

—The Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister have made it clear that, in the absence of a United Nations peacekeeping force-that absence being because of the Russian veto-the Commonwealth Government would view the need for a balanced force, a peacekeeping force-its view of balance would be that it should have essentially Western European representation in a significant way-as one that would comprise the United Kingdom in particular and hopefully Canada. As things stand at the moment, it looks as though France-socialist France, incidentally-has indicated that it finds virtue in such a peacekeeping force. The United Kingdom, Holland and Italy may well do so. The position of Canada is not clear. My understanding is that the Commonwealth Government would believe that if it were possible to get a peacekeeping force involving such a wide range of Western European countries it would fulfil the description that the Commonwealth had in mind.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. My understanding was that Canadian involvement was a necessary prerequisite for Australian involvement. Is that still the position or was I wrong in the assumption that Canadian involvement was a prerequisite?

—As I indicated, the Prime Minister, early in his statements on the establishment of a Sinai peacekeeping force, had indicated that a force which for example included the United Kingdom and Canada would be a balanced force. Subsequently, because of the strong potential inflow of Western European countries such as France, the United Kingdom, Holland and Italy, the Government has indicated that that would be regarded as a balanced force.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Leader's attention been drawn to the dynamic policy statement given to the media this week by Tasmania's new Liberal leader, Mr Robin Gray? Does the Minister agree that Mr Gray's new plan offers the leadership and incentive which when implemented should lead to a considerable revision of Tasmania's dependence on Canberra and an enormous lift to Tasmania's overall economy? Will the Federal Government give all assistance possible to develop the matters raised in Mr Gray's forward looking strategy?

—It was refreshing to hear from a Tasmanian leader constructive policies for the restoration of Tasmania. It was refreshing when one considers the real troubles that the Labor Government in Tasmania has found itself in and its inability to face the realities of constructing an environment in Tasmania to give to the Tasmanian people a future with an assured living standard. I commend the statements that have been made. They are the first gleam of hope that Tasmania has had in many years.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. By way of preface I refer to her response of 22 September indicating that the Australian Government thought the inter-communal discussions in Cyprus would achieve peace. In view of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting communique which indicated to the contrary-in fact it indicated impatience with the lack of progress-and in view of the forthcoming United Nations discussions, will we initiate action that would urge the United States to get away from its fixation on the Turkey-North Atlantic Treaty Organisation membership which seems to blur its vision on accepting the Cypriot Government's terms for peace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is the Government's understanding that the next session of the inter-communal talks will take place on or about 18 November. At this session it is expected that the United Nations representative will table a report prepared under the auspices of the United Nations Secretary-General which attempts to delineate the common ground between the two sides and suggests avenues for carrying the talks forward. The Government continues to believe that the inter-communal talks provide the most appropriate forum in which to pursue a solution to the Cyprus question. The Government hopes that the constructive atmosphere which has prevailed at the talks since their resumption last year will continue and that the negotiations will provide the basis of a lasting settlement to the Cyprus question which is satisfactory to both communities.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the actions of two members of the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australia at the central sterilising and linen supply centre at Mitchell? Is the Minister aware that these men are conducting rolling strikes, notwithstanding the fact that they have accepted pay rises for themselves, that they are holding the community to ransom and are trying to disrupt hospital services by these strikes in support of other members of the union who are employed elsewhere? Will the Minister consider terminating their employment?

—I am aware of expressions of concern that have come from the Chairman of the Capital Territory Health Commission. I must say that any action which would tend to deprive a community of health care as a point of leverage in industrial negotiations, especially when one is negotiating for other people, seems to me to be socially irresponsible.
—Physician, heal thyself.

—I am surprised that the Australian Labor Party does not want to endorse that position. The two drivers are causing the Capital Territory Health Commission to run low on supplies. If this happens the only people who will lose will be the patients in the Australian Capital Territory who are looking for care and service. I understand that the members of the union concerned are off work today. To that extent the situation in the Australian Capital Territory becomes more difficult. I understand that the Capital Territory Health Commission is running low on supplies. These are the supplies which are needed to care for and treat patients. The two members of the union have been offered the requested pay rise of $21 a week. There is no valid reason for them to continue to take this industrial action. Because the health area is a sensitive one the union is using the action of a few to affect many members of the community. I think that by affecting their access to health care they are doing it in an improper way. I make it quite clear that the members who are on strike are doing so for other members of their union who are employed outside the health area. I believe that makes their actions totally reprehensible.

—On 29 October 1981 Senator Coates asked me a question concerning the building industry in Tasmania. I now have an answer for him. The timetable adopted by the Commonwealth for the Hobart law courts project provides for commencement of construction by Christmas 1981. This timetable remains unchanged. A total of 23 tenders were submitted for the building and nominated subcontract work. Of these, 14 included qualifications in respect of reimbursement of extra costs relating to reduced working hours or special allowances. Tenders are at present being evaluated. Policy applicable to Commonwealth projects provides that fixed prices apply to contracts of less than nine months duration. Contracts of longer duration include provision for adjustment of wages, allowance of wages, allowances and loadings on a formula basis which recognises variations to awards or other statutory prescriptions which are of general application throughout the industry and are not related exclusively to a particular contract, contractor or contract site. In those few instances where unique circumstances apply, such as special hazards for workers, specifications include provision for the reimbursement of special allowances awarded by an appropriate tribunal. Since the law courts project, located near the middle of Hobart, does not have special features, provision for reimbursement was not included in the advertised specification. This policy is directed to containment of the incidence of over-award or other special payments and is kept under review from time to time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Sibraa proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for Australian food aid for Poland.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party's attitude to events in Poland is clear. Our support is based on our traditional commitment to trade union rights, our commitment to democratic institutions, our belief that the process of detente would open Eastern Europe to Western trade and bring with it economic and political influence. This has undoubtedly happened in the case of Poland. Our support is based also on our belief that Solidarity is a genuine workers movement and that what has been occurring in Poland has been a genuine workers revolution. My colleague, Senator Robert Ray, will deal with the Solidarity movement in greater detail when he makes his contribution to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We also made quite clear to the Soviet Union what our position was on Poland. On 25 March 1981 the Leader of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party, Bill Hayden, wrote to the Soviet Ambassador in Canberra as follows:

The Federal Parliamentary Labor Party would like you to convey to your Government its strongest opposition to any intervention by Soviet armed forces or other Warsaw Pact countries in the internal affairs of Poland.

We believe that such a course of action will do irreparable damage to the process of detente seriously endangering world peace. Such action would be in breach of the principles of non-intervention in the internal affairs of sovereign states.
Mr Hayden went on to say:
The Federal Parliamentary Labor Party would like you to make clear to your Government that it would share in the sense of outrage that would accompany any such intervention . . .
I seek leave to have the full text of that letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
25 March 1981
His Excellency
Dr N. G. Soudarikov,
Ambassador for the Union of Soviet
Socialist Republics,
78 Canberra Avenue,
Griffith, ACT 2603
Your Excellency,

The Federal Parliamentary Labor Party would like you to convey to your Government its strongest opposition to any intervention by Soviet armed forces or other Warsaw Pact countries in the internal affairs of Poland.

We believe that such a course of action will do irreparable damage to the process of detente seriously endangering world peace. Such action would be in breach of the principles of non-intervention in the internal affairs of sovereign states.

We note with concern the extension of Warsaw Pact manoeuvres in Poland and strongly urge that such pressure on the Polish Government and people should cease. The Polish people are entitled to solve their own problems without external interference.
Relations between the Soviet Union and Australia, which have already been damaged by the invasion of Afghanistan, would further deteriorate should armed intervention take place.

The Federal Parliamentary Labor Party would like you to make clear to your Government that it would share in the sense of outrage that would accompany any such intervention, and would regard it as placing in serious jeopardy the prospect of any useful relations between a future Labor Government and the Soviet Union.

It is in this regard that I have sought an appointment with you so that the concern of my Party can be conveyed to you. I thank you for agreeing to see me at 4 p.m. on Tuesday 31 March 1981 along with my Deputy, Lionel Bowen, and the President and Secretary of the FPLP Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, Mr R. Jacobi, and Mr K. Beazley. Given the uncertainties of a Parliamentary sitting day, I would much appreciate it if our meeting could take place in my office at Parliament House.
I look forward to discussing this and other issues whose resolution is essential if there is to be any possibility of a more healthy and positive future for Australian/Soviet relations.
Yours sincerely,
BILL HAYDEN M.P.
Leader of the Federal Parliamentary
Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Federal Parliamentary Labor Party Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee has also met on this subject a number of times. We have had before us the Polish Ambassador, the former Australian Ambassador in Poland and, on two occasions, officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs, to brief us on the matter. The subject must be viewed in light of the total world situation at the moment, particularly that in Europe at a time of increased tension between the super-powers. As we were reminded at Question Time today, we have had United States Government spokesmen talking about a limited winnable nuclear war in Europe. Obviously, their counterparts, the hawks in the Kremlin, would be planning a winnable conventional strike into Western Europe. What is happening in Western Europe at the moment is that a huge and genuine peace movement is present and growing. I know that people, including probably honourable senators on the Government side, will say that many of the peace movements in Europe have been sponsored by the Soviet Union. I do not deny that there is some Soviet influence in those peace movements but at the moment we are seing a huge and spontaneous gathering of Europeans who are worried that they might be placed in the middle of a nuclear war. It is a Europe in which each of the major cities is nuclear targeted with the equivalent of 2,000 Hiroshima-type atomic bombs, a Europe where the West German Government, because of statements by the President of the United States and pressure from President Brezhnev of the Soviet Union, could be destroyed and in its place we would get a hard line right wing government that would certainly not hesitate to deploy Cruise missiles in West Germany.

SPEECH.PARA: I was reminded recently of a statement by Senator Church, the former Chairman of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who said in Canberra on 21 October:
There is no such thing as limited nuclear war. Any nuclear exchange would quickly escalate out of control. Any talk of limited nuclear war is unreal.

Yet at the moment we have just such talk taking place in Europe. There is also evidence of unrest in Eastern Europe outside of Poland. I refer to Romania. The distribution of dissident pamphlets coincided with two explosions in Ploiesti, the Romanian oil producing centre. The Romanian economy is under great strain at the moment. It has become an importer of oil from the Soviet Union, as opposed to its position a few years ago when it was an oil exporter. Romania faces a $2 billion repayment in Western loans this year alone. It is quite apparent that Romania's highly independent foreign policy in relation to the Soviet Union has led to a number of Romanians dreaming the Polish dream. Despite strict crackdowns on internal dissent in Romania at the moment, there are signs of unrest. Recently a trade union organisation calling itself Unity asked for a general strike to take place. This strike did not take place, but all of these things are evidence of unrest outside Poland.

I think it would be fair to say that there is a great deal of political unease throughout Europe, East and West, excluding the situation in Poland. In looking at the situation in Poland at the moment I think we have to remember that since World War II, as a result of food supply shortages and price increases, there have been revolts by the Polish people. Rigid communist regimes have been brought down and replaced. Now there is a liberalised Polish Government, and Solidarity is threatened because of food shortages and price increases.

Prime Ministe Jaruzelski and Deputy Prime Minister Rakowski are probably the last leaders in the Communist Party in Poland who are capable of pursuing a non-violent and non-confrontationist approach to the trade union movement. Jaruzelski is a Polish Army general. The Army is well regarded in Poland; it is a people's army. The large basis of that Army is still conscripted from among the Polish people. As I said, it is well regarded, as opposed to the police force in Poland which is not well regarded by the people. Deputy Prime Minister Rakowski is a moderate. Many members of the Australian Parliament will remember when he paid a visit here. I think it was in 1976 or 1977. I remember the then Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, Sir Magnus Cormack, remarking that he was perhaps one of the most open and most liberal people from Eastern Europe he ever had the pleasure of meeting. I know that he is highly regarded by the Australian Embassy in Warsaw. As I said previously, both these men are probably the last chance that the Communist Party in Poland has of pursuing a responsible approach to the trade union movement.

Solidarity is controlled by the moderates at the moment. It is a working class movement; it is not a movement of dissaffected intellectuals or students, but that is not to say that it will always remain such. Poland's economic situation at the moment is disastrous. It has a $27 billion deficit to the West. Poland has come close to defaulting on several occasions. Complex debt rescheduling has staved it off in the case of payments of $US4.4 billion due last financial year. Some 460 Western banks are involved in bankrolling its debt, and the implications of collapse for the Western banking system are monstrous. For example, in 1979, 83 per cent of its new borrowings were used in the repayment of existing debts. The problem of repayment of debt is largely a function of another feature of the Polish economy, and that is the collapse of the export earning industries. Most specifically this has occurred in the coal industry. In 1979, 41 million tonnes of coal were exported. The 1981 planned figure was 24 million. But even with this dramatic reduction it appears that only 2 million tonnes were sold in the first quarter of the year, so that target will not be reached. The problem is a product of inefficient organisation and industrial unrest. There is a massive requirement for importation of foodstuffs. In large measure this is a product of long term agricultural mismanagement. The impact requirement will be some 10 million tonnes, which will pose further problems for Poland's foreign indebtness.

I think a question that all of us have to ask ourselves is this: Will the Soviet Union intervene? The Soviets have historically allowed Poland a greater freedom of action than any of its other satellites. It has no common border with the West, therefore the Soviets argue that it is limited in outside influence. Evidence is emerging at the moment that the Soviets have tolerated the recent moves to include Solidarity and the church in a type of coalition government. That is a type of coalition they would not allow to exist anywhere else in Eastern Europe. I believe the Soviet Union will not invade unless there is a complete collapse of the Polish Communist Party, and I believe that is on the cards in the coming winter.

The cost to the Soviet Union of intervention would be the assumption of a $27 billion debt. If the Soviets defaulted, it would throw into chaos Western economic relationships with all of the other Eastern bloc countries. The probable conclusion of favourable detente-based trading relations with the West, including high technology imports from Japan and Germany in particular, would be at risk. An American blockade, and possibly even an invasion of Cuba, could take place if the Soviets invaded Poland. They would have to examine the military costs involved in fighting a well trained, substantial, if inferior, force in Poland. They would also have to look very carefully at the type of world reaction that followed the Soviet Union's incursion into Afghanistan.

In light of all these circumstances, Australia should provide unconditional food aid to Poland. Meat, sugar and grain immediately come to mind. On 7 August 1981 Mr Beazley, the honourable member for Swan in Western Australia, wrote to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) along those lines. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the reply of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to Mr Beazley.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Foreign Affairs Canberra Dear Mr Beazley

I refer to your letter of 7 August 1981, in which you urge the Government to offer substantial food aid to Poland. I appreciate your interest in the Polish situation and agree entirely with your analysis of the relationship in Poland between the Government, the Solidarity leadership and the rank and file. It is clear that the economy continues to worsen, that shortages are becoming more acute, that strike action will not resolve these problems, and that the potential for serious social unrest and disorder is great while these economic difficulties persist. In those circumstances, the possibility of outside intervention cannot be discounted. The key to Polish economic revival lies in the rapid formulation and implementation of reform measures, which will probably include price rises and wage freezes. Solidarity's cooperation will be required if these measures are to be introduced with minimal public disorder.

Western economic assistance, in the form of debt rescheduling and food and financial aid, will play an important part in assisting Poland to weather the coming months until the economy is revitalised. In response to requests for assistance from the Polish Government, a number of West European governments, the EEC and the United States and Canadian governments have initiated steps to provide Poland with much-needed foodstuffs, medical supplies and other products. A meeting of Western bankers in Zurich in July formulated a proposal for the rescheduling of Poland's hard-currency debt and the Polish Government is considering this proposal at present.

The above facts demonstrate that Western governments appreciate Poland's need for assistance. The Australian Government also appreciates that need. It was for this reason that, in April of this year, the Government agreed to provide credit guarantees to facilitate the purchase, by Poland, of up to $A40m worth of wool and hides.

In response to your letter, and similar representations from the Polish community in Australia, departments have under preliminary study the question of what further aid Australia may be in a position to offer Poland in the event that a formal request is made to the Government. As you know, we have not received a request from Poland for further assistance. This makes it difficult for us to determine Poland's precise needs at this time and to know whether there is room for Australian action in the light of what others are contributing, including those countries better placed than Australia to respond urgently to the present crisis. It is also unprecedented for Australia to grant such aid to an East European country, and this is a further factor which needs to be taken into account. Nevertheless, we shall continue to examine the issue to determine what options, if any, are open to the Government.
Yours sincerely A. A. STREET

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister said in his reply that it would be unprecedented for Australia to grant aid to an Eastern European country. I think we have to look at the facts and realise that the European Economic Community and the French Government have already delivered food aid to the Polish people. Australia has to learn to react as the need arises and to grant aid to countries which are in urgent need, even though they may not normally be included in our assistance program. Poland is facing an acute food and fuel shortage this winter. Widespread hunger and discomfort will undoubtedly force the Polish people to go to greater and riskier lengths to achieve a reasonable standard of living. However, the facts show that the Polish Government is not in a position to grant even the basic necessities because it does not have the food or fuel stocks available to meet the needs of the people. If the Australian Government wishes to see the great advances in democratic rights in Poland continued and strengthened, now more than ever Australia must take a constructive stand and make substantial grants of food aid to Poland. There can be no question that the substantial democratic gains made by the Polish people over the last year or so, mainly through trade union activity, are being threatened by Poland's serious economic crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: If Australia now fails to respond to Poland's great need for food aid and consequently the fragile links between Solidarity and the Polish Government are shattered, the repercussions would be felt world wide. Firstly, if Poland defaults on her debts this could well lead to a major collapse in the Western banking system, especially if problems appeared elsewhere in Eastern Europe. Secondly, if the United States decided on an economic boycott of the Soviet Union our trading relationships would be seriously damaged. Thirdly, Poland's attempts to befriend the West and loosen the grip of the Soviet Union would be smashed, perhaps for good. Australia has no legitimate reason to ignore Poland's plight, and if the Government is sincere in its support for Solidarity and the more liberal style Polish Government it should immediately take steps to grant massive amounts of food aid to the Polish Government. The time is fast running out for both Solidarity and Jaruzelski, and the opportunity for the Australian Government to offer assistance may not arrive again.

In conclusion, I would like to quote from an article on America's new foreign policy written by Senator Frank Church, who is a former Chairman of the United States Foreign Relations Committee, to which I referred earlier. In dealing in this article with the involvement of the United States with the Soviet Union, he states:

There is something schizophrenic about the Reagan Administration's obsession with the Soviet Union. On the one hand, we are led to believe that the Russians are out to dominate the world. On the other hand, in an American version of historical inevitability, Mr Reagan assures us that we are seeing not only in Poland but in 'the reports that are beginning to come out of Russia itself . . . an indication that Communism is an aberration . . . the beginning of the end.' In short, the Russian Empire is cracking up. Mr Haig endorses the President's verdict: 'I think we are witnessing a historic unraveling of Marxist-Leninism on the Soviet model.'

If this is the case, then why all the anxiety? I suggest it has less to do with an overblown fear that the Soviet Union will ever dominate the world than with a gnawing worry that the Russians, desperate to hold their crumbling empire together, will lash out with their immense military machine.
I happen to think that Senator Church is right. I believe that by not granting substantial food aid to Poland now we might bring about just such a situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sibraa has brought forward as a matter of public importance today the need for Australian food aid for Poland. I say at the outset that the Government is well aware of the very real humanitarian problems now facing the Polish nation as a whole in finding enough food, medicine and clothing. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) announced yesterday, he will make a brief visit to Poland next week in the course of a wider visit to the United States and Europe. The Minister for Foreign Affairs will be going at the invitation of the Polish Foreign Minister, whom he met at the United Nations in New York earlier this year. The Minister is looking forward to having further discussions with the Polish Foreign Minister and with others in the Polish Government about a range of international and bilateral matters. In the brief time available to the Minister in Warsaw it may also be possible for him to have contact with other representatives of Polish society. If that is the case he would then be able to form a better understanding of developments within Poland. Throughout their present difficulties the Polish authorities have maintained their relations with other countries including Western countries, a number of whose representatives have visited Warsaw in the past year. The visit of the Australian Foreign Minister will be the first by an Australian Government Minister since 1975 and the first visit by a Foreign Minister of Australia. In 1978 we were pleased to receive a visit to Australia by the then Polish Foreign Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been no easing of the serious economic decline which has accompanied the political crisis of the past year in Poland. The consequences of economic deprivation and hardship cannot be seen in isolation or separated from the political significance of what is occurring in Poland. There is a risk that extreme hardship could lead to a breakdown in public order, which in turn could provoke external intervention. I think these matters were mentioned by Senator Sibraa in the speech we have just heard. It is in the interests of all countries that every effort should be made to prevent such a catastrophe. It is for this reason that many countries have responded sympathetically to Poland's various requests for economic assistance during the past year. For example, a number of Western countries well placed to assist, such as the United States, Canada and the countries of the European Economic Community, have extended to Poland various forms of credit to enable Poland to continue buying essential supplies and commodities in spite of her lack of hard currency. Western banks and creditor governments have also responded favourably and generously to Poland's urgent request for credit assistance and a debt rescheduling. I should stress that the kind of assistance Western countries are giving to Poland is, as far as we are aware, substantially in various forms of credit and not in grant aid. It is encouraging that Poland has now sought to rejoin the International Monetary Fund, an act which, if successful, should further assist Poland to restore her economy.

It is also to be noted that the Soviet Union has provided additional aid and economic assistance to Poland in response to the current situation, as have other of Poland's allies in the Warsaw Pact. The Australian Government has no confirmation of recent suggestions appearing in the Australian Press that the Soviet Union has refused economic assistance to Poland or is planning a winter blockade. Such reports appear to be unfounded.

As honourable senators will be aware, Australia granted credit guarantee assistance to Poland in April of this year to the extent of $40m. The purpose of that credit was to enable Poland to continue buying, in the main, Australian wool as well as some other products with the primary purpose of keeping factories in key areas operating. To that extent Australia's assistance has had an important humanitarian aim. This form of assistance was unprecedented in Australia's relations with an Eastern European country but was agreed to by the Government in view of the important considerations we are now discussing.

I should emphasise that Australia's assistance was given in response to a direct request from the Polish authorities. I am happy to say that Polish importers have made very good use of the facility provided through this assistance that we were able to give them. The Government has not received any further requests for assistance from the Polish authorities. Were such requests to come I have no doubt that the Australian Government would examine them carefully. If we were able to meet those requests we would give to them the same sort of sympathetic consideration that we gave to the request with which we dealt earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might not that humiliate them? Why not be generous?

—That is right. I think we would need to look at what requests were made and how we could respond to them. We were able to respond favourably to the request that was made and, as I have said, no further request has been made to this time. It should be understood that Australia is not as well placed as other countries to give Poland the kind of assistance she needs most urgently in the current circumstances. By that I mean that the most essential food commodities and medicines are more readily available from nearby European countries and from the United States. It is natural that for reasons of availability and transport convenience Poland should have turned first to those countries.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been speaking of Government assistance up to the present but I do not wish to overlook the very large amount of assistance which has been flowing to Poland in the past year from private sources. Those sources are numerous and wide. There has been a very ready response from a number of sources around the world. The Government understands that in Australia individuals and groups, particularly those of Polish origin, have mounted a very large effort in the past year and the value of their gifts of cash and kind can be measured in millions of dollars. I believe that that effort, which is continuing, deserves the very highest commendation. Similar private and community campaigns to assist Poland have been operating in many countries and we may imagine that this has resulted in a very large flow of essential commodities.

The Government is aware of reports that there is soon to be launched in Australia a nationwide appeal to co-ordinate private and community assistance to Poland. I understand that those reports are substantially correct but I am not yet in a position to provide any details of the manner in which the Government might respond to or associate itself with such an appeal. However, as I mentioned, the Minister for Foreign Affairs will be visiting Poland next week and as a result of that visit I am sure we will have a better understanding of the present situation in Poland and the needs of the Government and people of Poland. I feel sure that when the Minister returns a full and complete report will be available to the Australian Government for its consideration. In the meantime this nationwide appeal that we understand is to be launched soon, for community and private assistance, is one that would also have our consideration. At the appropriate time we will be able to respond to any appeal of that nature.

We welcome the opportunity to discuss this matter in the Senate today. I know that a number of honourable senators wish to speak on it, to put forward their own thoughts and perhaps provide information that is within their knowledge. If that is so then this is a matter that the Senate can very usefully discuss on this occasion. I thank those who will take part in the debate. I undertake to draw to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs the comments that will be made during the debate this afternoon and, as I have said, as a result of the Government's consideration of further developments and further information resulting from the Minister's visit we may be in a position to announce any further action that the Government may feel it is appropriate to take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The emergence of Solidarity-and its concern with the rights of workers and their families-has laid to rest the myth that workers are satisfied with how society is run and that discontent is limited to just a handful of misguided intellectuals. In Poland, practically an entire working class of people have demanded their basic rights. Solidarity has worked closely with the human rights committee KSS-KOR which emerged after the 1976 disturbances in central Poland. Six of the 14 original members of the Workers' Defence Committee-the KOR-were members of the pre-war Polish Socialist Party. The unofficial workers' journal, Robotnik, was also the name of the pre-war PSP newspaper.

SPEECH.PARA: The wave of strikes from Wroclaw to Warsaw to Gdansk in July-August 1980 led to the creation of independent trade unions, gathered in Solidarity. The old government unions, the Polish Trade Union Federation, virtually disintegrated as hundreds of thousands of workers went to Solidarity. Old officials did everything to stop the movement, reconstituted themselves as 'independent self-governing unions' and embraced the principles of Solidarity. Old unions did not challenge the Leninist conception of unions as 'transmission belts from the Party to the masses'. Edmund Baluka, chairman of the Szczecin Shipyards Strike Committee in 1970, pointed out:

The Statutes of the Polish United Workers' Party state that 'the party directs the political line of the trade unions', and the statutes of the trade unions in turn state that 'the trade unions carry out the correct line of the PUWP in the interests of the working class and the Polish nation.
Professor Rajkiewicz, neither a KOR nor a Solidarity member but rather a Government negotiator in the Gdansk talks of the summer of 1980, said of the pre-August unions:
Their first duty was (according to the Constitution) to co-operate with the authorities in plan fulfilment. The defence of employees' interests was secondary. Democracy disappeared altogether.

In 1978, the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, to which the Australian Council of Trade Unions is affiliated, and the International Metalworkers Federation lodged a complaint against the Polish Government with the Committee on Freedom of Association of the International Organisation. The ICFTU contended that 'the defence of the workers' interests is no longer assured by the official trade unions, which are imposed upon the workers since only (registered unions) are allowed legally to exist'. The ILO Committee concluded that Poland had contravened ILO Convention 87 of 1948 on Freedom of Association, which Poland had voluntarily adopted. The Convention guarantees that 'workers, without distinction whatsoever, should have the right to establish organisations of their own choosing without previous authorisation'.

The right to strike was granted in 1956 after the Poznan riots but was rescinded in following years. In fact, old union officials are on record in Polish newspapers as admitting that 'we had no courage to reach for the most effective weapon-the strike'. Traditionally, the infamous Article 52 of the Labour Code effectively prohibited strikes, by defining them as 'serious violations' of a worker's 'obligations', for which he might be fired without notice. This is something that honourable senators opposite might like to reintroduce. The sackings after the June 1976 disturbances were based on it-a classic anti-strike law. Polish workers were repressed in three ways: Firstly, measures affecting the unemployed worker; secondly, measures affecting the dissident worker; thirdly, measures affecting general working conditions. Unemployment, and unemployment benefits, were ideologically non-existent. Harassment was the reward of workers out of step with the official unions. Safety and conditions were secondary to production requirements. Since August last year, Solidarity has established itself as the first free trade union movement to succeed in a communist country. Zbigniew Gryszkiewicz, a Solidarity lawyer who toured the United States of America earlier this year, stated:

The vast majority of Solidarity members are extraordinarily responsible, and excessive demands will never be permitted to threaten our achievements. We want to be an ordinary trade union, which is perhaps rather difficult in a country like ours. But we are learning, the authorities are slowly learning, and I believe there is enough of a reservoir of goodwill and realism on both sides for our wishes to become reality.

This month has seen joint talks between the Polish United Workers Party-that is the Communist Party-the Catholic Church and the Solidarity trade union. These talks represent an unprecedented recognition by the current regime of the political and civic rights defended by the trade union movement. In a joint communique issued on 4 November the possibility of a 'Front of National Agreement' was canvassed.

This month has also seen talks directed towards the re-entry of Poland into the International Monetary Fund, as was mentioned by the previous speaker, the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle). Allegedly, Moscow has accepted IMF membership for Poland as the price of economic stability. After a decade of intensive industrial development, funded by over 400 Western banks, 64 of them in the United States, Poland has debts in the West of at least $20 billion and possibly $27 billion, as was mentioned earlier. The United States has extended $60m worth of grain credits to Poland and has proposed multi-billion dollar credits on a 50-50 East-West basis. The Soviet Union itself has extended over $3,600m in credit and deferred payments since August 1980.
What can Australia do? Gryszkiewicz suggests that Solidarity is not really interested in pious propaganda. Nor do we want any money, any dollars. He went on to say:
The US union council AFL-CIO has sent more than $200,000; the Scandinavian unions have helped with organisation, printing presses, typewriters, etc.

But what Solidarity needs above all is medical help. Medications, surgical instruments and the like. The State of our country's pharmacological industry is catastrophic. This has been officially admitted. Millions of people live on the edge of poverty, and in poor health. Our Ministry of Public Health is actually very much interested in Solidarity's efforts to secure more medications and parts for our hospitals, creches, rest homes, clinics and so on. This is my primary task here in the States-to obtain medical help for our 10 million members and their families-not an insignificant portion of the population, as you can imagine.

The Solidarity Association of Poles in Australia, based in Sydney, has organised a medicines for Poland appeal which in its first week received medicines worth $18,000 and $2,000 in donations. As the Minister for Finance has indicated, that organisation has been most successful in the months since its foundation.

Solidarity overall is the most significant development in communist countries since the first one came into existence in 1917. Its importance has spread far beyond the borders of Poland. For that reason alone I believe Australia has a responsibility to offer useful aid. Every effort should be made to defuse the tension between the state and the working class movement. Talk of confrontation may satisfy anti-Soviet egos but, as Lech Walesa was reported in Australian media on 11 November as saying, the intervention of Moscow could result in 'the slaughter of one third of the nation'. That horrible prospect would be a monstrous end to Solidarity.

I believe it is up to all Australian citizens to support food aid to Poland. We do not want to see a repeat of Budapest in 1956 or Prague in 1968. The threat of Soviet intervention in Poland will only be enhanced if the basic fabric of Polish society breaks down and if; in this coming winter, which will be the most crucial time, food and medical supplies are not available to the Polish people. In the last year we have seen the establishment of one of the biggest trade union or mass movements in world history. That union has grown from nothing to having 10 million members in 12 months. If we as Australian democrats do not support that movement, in my view all our speeches on the faults of the Soviet Union and everything else go to water. I commend the matter of public importance and urge the Government to take some action on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Sibraa has brought forward this matter of public importance because it is very important. I think the Senate has to address itself to three issues: How did Poland get itself into such an economic mess; how can it get out of it; and what assistance, if any, should we provide to help it to do so? Let us look at the first question, namely, how it got into its present economic mess. There is no doubt that Poland is in an economic mess. Just as a few examples, meat, sugar, butter, flour and rice are among the foods now on ration. But even rationing has not been enough to ensure supplies. The meat ration these days is three kilograms per person per month. But still the queues at butchers' shops start 24 hours before opening time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only meat that is desperately short. As usual the Poles have summed up the situation with one of their jokes. They define a Polish sandwich as being a meat coupon between two bread coupons. Everyone talks about the black market where meat and other foods fetch four or five times the official price. At the moment a husband coming off night shift will often take his wife's place in a queue and often whole families will queue at one shop. That may be the only time in days that the whole family can get together. In fact, absenteeism in order to queue is having a very serious effect on Polish production and some observers think it is a more serious cause of loss of production than are strikes.

Why are the Poles short of food? After all, Poland is a very fertile agricultural country and it should at least be self-supporting. I think there is no doubt that the catastrophic state of Polish agriculture is the result of communist dogma. In a way I wish that Senator Gietzelt were taking part in this debate. He could probably explain to the Senate how it is all the fault of America. I believe it is quite clearly the result of the application of the communist system under which very inefficient state farms have been established and there has been discrimination against private farmers. Foreign capital has been squandered on those state farms and of course the farmers have been denied the machinery and fertilisers they need. The price of meat has been so poor that it is no longer worth breeding pigs for the market.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is much worse in Poland than in any other Eastern European country.

—Yes, it may well be, although I think all Eastern European countries or communist countries have deplorable productivity, and Poland, of course, is only one example of that. One thing that is happening is that Poland's one and a quarter million worker peasants are dividing their time between working in industry and farming. If they want to get more productivity they should certainly devote more of their time to agriculture. The other enormous problem for Poland is that it is $US27 billion in debt to the West, and the rolling over of this debt is one of the biggest problems facing both the West and Poland. Not only, of course, has Poland's problem been caused by the application of communist dogma but it has also been compounded by the reaction of the people to the communist dogma and their attempts to set up free institutions, the Solidarity trade union movement being the best publicised. This has made the problem worse in the short term, though it does, of course, hold out hopes for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: That really brings us to the second question-how can Poland get out of its present mess? One solution, I suppose, would be to go back to rigid communism. That would at least get people back to work and improve productivity a little. It would still be deplorable but it would improve it a little. I do not think that that is a solution that we would recommend or that the Polish people, having tried it once, would accept. The only way I think such a solution would happen would be if the Soviet Union imposed it.

We have had an exposition from Senator Sibraa, with which I agree, of why it is unlikely that the Soviet Union will intervene in Poland. Poland is not like Hungary or Czechoslovakia. There the Communist Party was still in control. All that the Soviet Union had to do was to exterminate the liberals who were running the Communist Party, impose its own people, and the party machine structure was still in place. If the Soviet Union moved now into Poland, it could take over the government, yes; but how could it impose the government's will on the trade union movement and the people of Poland? There would be fighting; there would be strikes; there would be an intolerable economic situation which would be worse than it is now and, moreover, the Soviet Union would have to take on the responsibility of financing Poland without any assistance from the West. I think that is a prospect that the Soviet Union is not prepared to face.

In considering how Poland can get out of its situation we must realise that Poland has a lot going for it. It has large coal resources; it is the biggest sulphur producer in the world; it has large reserves of iron ore; it has a highly efficient shipbuilding industry; it is expert in electronics; it has a young and skilled work force. It has, if properly managed, a very great deal going for it. What we must look for is some way in which we can assist it or try to prevent it from being stopped from sorting out its internal situation, getting people back to work, giving incentives, getting the highly inefficient government regulation system off the back of the Polish economy because, as I said, Poland has a lot going for it.

When we look at the sort of economic aid Poland needs from the West, we must avoid the mistakes of the attempts in the early 1970s to give it aid when Western loans underwrote the mismanaged and ill-founded schemes of the discredited Polish communist leader, Edward Gierek. This aid for Poland would come mostly from the European Economic Community and the United States, and what I hope will be achieved is that the loans will be conditional on the restructuring of the whole economic system in Poland and the jettisoning of the terribly anti-productivity government regulation system and its incentives and economic planning systems, which are totally destructive of any desire to produce any efficient production system. That, I think, would have to be encouraged by the way in which economic assistance is given to Poland.

We have already given Poland some assistance. As requested by the Polish Government, we made available to it $40m in credits for the purchases of wool in order to keep its wool mills going. That is what the Polish Government asked for and we provided it, and it is working. That is one type of assistance that is valuable. Poland has a very great and urgent need for food assistance. As Senator Guilfoyle said, because of convenience and availability the main providers of this assistance, will be Western Europe, the European Economic Community. But we can and should help where we can provide important assistance. So far, I am told, $5m has been given in personal aid, mainly through the churches, by people chiefly of Polish origin. I think this should be encouraged. There will, I understand, be a new appeal for food aid for Poland launched in a few weeks. I hope the Government will support this appeal and make a donation and encourage donations to the appeal by offering tax deductibility because I think it is important that the present ferment in Poland should not collapse and Russian involvement and invasion be encouraged through turmoil resulting from food shortages.
