TALK.START.PARA: —On a bitterly cold day in January of this year a cluster of farmers came together and marched into the tiny village of Inowroclaw in Central Poland. It was a demonstration in support of Rural Solidarity, the peasants' union that the Government of that country had up to that moment been refusing to recognise. What was important was that the peasants who were then marching, the protesters there involved, carried their scythes fixed vertically on to the wooden shafts like giant bayonets and, as any Pole will tell us, that has quite a deal of symbolism to it. In 1794 under Kosciusko, the American revolutionary war hero who had returned to Poland to help his people in what turned out to be a doomed insurrection against the Russian and Prussian occupiers, that is how Kosciusko's troops armed themselves-with their scythes on wooden shafts. Our most noble and highest peak in Australia is called Kosciusko after that Polish revolutionary hero. I hope that links can be forged once again between the Australian and the Polish people, not of a merely symbolic or geographical kind but, as is commended to the Senate today, of a real humanitarian kind, of a kind which not only satisfies the hunger of the people of Poland in the coming severe winter but also satisfies their craving to establish a truly democratic society in which the lives of the industrial workers, the urban workers and the peasants are humanised.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Polish peasants should not be held responsible for the present dire shortage of foodstuffs for their countrymen. As we know, the Polish Government cannot afford to import food to any great extent. That is due to the catastrophic collapse of its export trade, particularly in coal. Whereas in 1979 some 41 million tonnes of Polish coal were sold abroad, it seems that in the coming year only some 2 million tonnes of coal will find their way to export markets. Honourable senators can imagine the catastrophic effect that has on the ability of the Polish Government to use hard currency earnings for the purchase of the meagre foodstuffs that are needed to sustain the people.

The farmers have been prevented from farming efficiently. That has been done by a system of selling to fixed and controlled markets; by a system which denies them fertiliser, tractors and such like unless they do indeed sell to those government-controlled markets; by a system which requires peasants to sell so much to the state market in order to guarantee their title to their land from year to year. Indeed, one of Rural Solidarity's claims-it asks that this be written into the Constitution-is that the farmers be given a title to their land. It is really a cry reminiscent of that of some of the Aboriginal people, of which we hear so much in this chamber. In fact, the Polish peasants are denied true title to their land. It is no wonder that there has been a catastrophic collapse of their ability to feed the nation, an ability which no one would deny could bring those lands to fruition if the farmers were allowed to gain access to the fertilisers, the pesticides and the equipment needed to make their lands flourish. But at the moment there is no doubt that as the winter approaches the Polish people will be hungry. It behoves us to try to alleviate that sheer human suffering.

Three years ago it was a severe winter which brought the regime of Edward Gierek to the brink. As Senator Sibraa so well pointed out, another severe winter without adequate food could prove the breaking point for Poland's last chance of staving off Russian-backed reassertion of hard-line Communist Party superiority. General Jaruzelski does appear to be negotiating with the new forces within the industrial working class, the peasants and the Catholic Church to provide a framework within which national decision making by Poles can take place. It may well be their last chance. There can be no doubt that the provision of food-the simple act of providing meat, wheat and sugar-will enable the Polish people to get through this winter without such crippling strikes or civic rioting as might precipitate that Soviet-backed reassertion of hard-line Communist Party authority.

In sending food we would not merely be alleviating distress of the body; I believe that we would indeed be succouring the Polish soul. We would be aiding a revolution, a revolution which has seen for the first time in Eastern Europe, on such a wide scale, the withdrawal of allegiance from the State and the Communist Party in favour of an organisation which, as Senator Robert Ray so well documented, was illegal a matter of months ago. It is a revolution which commands our support. It commands our support because of its evidently democratic basis. That it is democratic, that it is really based on the people, cannot be denied. The numbers, the tens of millions, who flocked to its banners are sufficient evidence of that. It should demand or require our support not only because it is a democratic movement but also because it has shown a non-violent character. I think that is something which has to be remarked upon and commended.

The people have formed free trade unions against the will of the party. They have exercised free speech against the will of the party. They have become free by courageously acting as a free people and they have done so non-violently and with tremendous courage. The party has been unable to grapple with this phenomenon because, indeed, this revolution by the people paradoxically proves one of Marx's hopes; namely, that the working people can take control of their destinies, can take control of their lives, can attempt to humanise their conditions of labour, within the industrial proletariat or as peasants on the land, and can humanise society as a whole. They can do that without the aid of the state, which has indeed withered away as far as the working people of Poland are concerned, and without the arrogant claims of the party to lead the proletariat into the future. These claims have been stripped bare by the courageous actions of the people of Poland so that the military and bureaucratic underpinning of the state has withered to an extent which now enables the coalition of forces-as I said, the industrial working class, the peasants, the Catholic Church and the Communist Party-to achieve some sort of national framework within which decisions can be made about Poland's future.

It is a fact though that as winter approaches, as the food queues grow longer, the constant strikes and civic unrest over food shortages which may occur could provide that context within which a reassertion of hard line Soviet-backed Communist Party authority could take place. Solidarity cannot be expected to control the cries of women wanting food for their children. The October and November Press of this year made that quite clear. For example, an article in the International Herald Tribune of 14 October, headed 'Some Sections Of Solidarity Go On Strike', reported that, whereas the presidium of Solidarity called for a moratorium on local strikes, it was disclosed that some regions after the presidium appeal decided to call off protests but others went ahead and about 10,000 workers in about 50 local plants in one area sat in to protest dwindling food supplies. In the first week of November about 12,000 women textile workers went on strike for more food despite the calls of Solidarity to restrain that sort of protest. It is quite clear that Solidarity will not be able to control this continuing disintegration, this continuing provocation to the hardliners within the Community Party in the absence of adequate food for the people during winter. For that reason, Australians must do what is possible to aid the Polish people to obtain that food. We are not talking about intervention by military means or about direct interference with the internal political affairs of that nation. We simply need to aid the people to eat and therefore to carry through their democratic revolution.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle mentioned that Mr Street, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, will be visiting Poland-I think she said next week-in the context of a wider European and United States of America tour. She made the point that it may be that Australia is not as advantageously placed as some other nations are to move aid into Poland expeditiously enough because of transport problems and such like. Surely it would not be beyond the wit of Mr Street and the Government to devise a means whereby Australian money can be used to purchase food from the European Economic Community, some minor fraction of the lake of milk and dairy products held by the Common Market, some minor hill within the mountain of meat which is held by the Common Market countries and some of the medical supplies which are so abundant in Western Europe. Surely the Australian Government could provide moneys directly for purchase of foodstuffs and medical supplies within Western Europe and move them by the shorter lines of transport directly into Poland.

On 7 August the French Socialist Government announced that it was rushing food aid-322,000 tonnes of grain, beef, sugar and fruit-to Poland with no political strings attached. If the new Socialist Government of France can respond with such alacrity and compassion, can we do less? On 28 October the United States Government announced it would supply Poland with $29m worth of surplus dairy products to help that country resolve its pressing difficulties peacefully and without foreign interference. Can we be any less realistic than the United States Government in that regard? After all, it is a fact that we trade extensively in foodstuffs with Warsaw Pact countries and with the Soviet Union, the potential oppressor of the Polish people. In the last year, 1980-81, we sent some $581m worth of food to the Soviet Union, of which $104m was in the area of meat or meat products and $486m in the area of cereal grains and preparations. One recalls the ill-conceived-and ill-dismantled-grain embargo of the Soviet Union after the Afghanistan invasion. Cannot we do something a little more constructive on this occasion? I believe the Australian people would want their Government to respond generously and expeditiously to the cries of the Polish people as they face a gruelling winter.

We have had a long association with the Polish people. As to my own State of Tasmania, as Senator Harradine may be about to remark, after the Second World War quite a few came to Tasmania to work on hydro-electric projects throughout the State. No doubt many other States have similar experience of the strength and hard work which the Polish people brought into Australia after the conflagration in Europe in the 1940s. We have historic links, symbolised by the naming of Mount Kosciusko, our most noble peak, after the revolutionary hero of Poland who was doomed to failure in his attempt to throw off the Russian yoke back in the 1790s. I hope that the link with the Polish people can be continued. As we see the changing colours of the trees and shrubs of Canberra next autumn, may we be able to be humbly grateful that, in part because of our support in the provision of basic foodstuffs, the Polish people will be entering their spring, a spring of the revival of nature and of a flowering of the Polish nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the need for Australian food aid to Poland. Indeed, I am not surprised to find around the chamber that there is a general consensus that there is such a need. It is our obligation, along with all the other fortunate free countries in the world, to do something about it. When there has been genuine need around the world-wherever it may have been-I think Australia historically has played its part to a very real and large degree. Of course, in the passage of time perhaps we have concentrated most of our efforts in what one probably considers to be the traditional areas for Australian aid and development programs. There are all sorts of geographical, social and economic reasons for that to be so.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time we have played, and continue to play, a significant role around the world in helping people confronted by emergency circumstances. This applies not necessarily just to the developing societies. Indeed, in the case of Poland we have a highly developed society which has run into extraordinarily difficult times for all sorts of reasons. One would hope and believe that this circumstance is not a continuing one. It certainly fits the description of being an emergency situation. In that sort of situation there are only a few limiting factors of which we as Australians must be aware. Of course, in the case of food, one factor would be our capacity to provide for the needs of the people concerned. There can be no doubt that Australia has a significant capacity in this field. In the fields of food production-of agriculture in particular-and of fibre production, Australia ranks as the most efficient, on a per capita basis, of any country in the world. Consequently, on those grounds it has a great capacity to lend aid.

Another factor to be considered is our financial capacity. I mention this only because one has, at all times, to relate the financial capacity-the burden of the Australian taxpayer-to the world of reality. Indeed, if we adopt conditions that in any significant way destroy the socio-economic level of Australians, equally we destroy our capacity to help those people in many places around the world who so urgently need help. I refer again to my earlier comment that we in Australia have a traditional area in which we have given significant aid and development over many decades. That significant area is South East Asia, the southern borders of the Asian continent itself, Africa, and, indeed, our near neighbours in the South Pacific. Whilst we give a significant priority to those parts of the mainly developing world, we are not unaware of our obligations wherever emergencies, such as the Polish situation arise.

One cannot discuss a matter such as the one we are talking of this afternoon without being aware of the tragedy there is when an old European country such as Poland is confronted with the sorts of problems that confront it today. The Polish people have a very proud record. They come from a productive and fertile land. Ironically they contributed very significantly, in the conflict of 1939-1945, to the survival of freedom in many parts of the world. Significantly, basically because of the imposition of a system which, in a sense, knows no freedom, they are today in the circumstance in which they find themselves and it is necessary for Australia and many other free societies around the world to come to their aid. Indeed, I believe there is something sad also in the fact that European countries have been, and remain, amongst the world's leaders in the field of temperate and sub-temperate agriculture, in the field of breeding of plants and stock, yet here we have a famous European country in significant danger of severe famine. Surely in this situation there must be considerable obligation on her Eastern neighbours to help. For indeed it is largely the political system and the socio-economic circumstances of those neighbours that Poland has adopted-probably without much opportunity to make a free decision. If that system is failing to produce the basic necessities of the Polish way of life then there is a massive obligation on her Eastern neighbours, as well as on the rest of the world, to come to her succour. As this food dilemma confronts the Polish people in particular-it is a dilemma that has gone far beyond food itself-it has to be asked whether in the Polish situation a totally inappropriate system of agriculture and pastoral development has been imposed. Bad seasons may well have played their part. As I understand it they have played their part in the circumstances of the Russian economy today. They may well have played a part in the circumstances in Poland. But I believe that the situation is more related to inappropriate systems of agriculture and pastoral development. Indeed, they perhaps relate to changes in the nature and traditions of the communities in Poland.

Australia makes a significant contribution to the supply of food around the world. Her contribution at the moment, measured in terms of percentage of gross domestic product, is 0.47 per cent. This is at a time when most countries around the world aim to reach 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product eventually. We must never forget that even though we retain our determination to reach that upper limit our capacity to do so is clearly related to the rate and enthusiasm of the development of our massive potential in the resources field.

I draw my remarks to a conclusion by saying once again that the Polish situation is a sad and serious one and that the Australian Government is aware of the problems and is making and will continue to make significant contributions to their solution. One measure has been mentioned here this afternoon; that is, the contribution of some $40m worth of credit. This has played a significant part in enabling Polish factories to keep moving, maintaining and developing a sense of achievement amongst Polish families and workers. It is esential that the world not only comes to the succour of Poland with the material needs that she has today but also that it helps, wherever necessary, to create circumstances in which the Polish people can establish once again the sort of society, objectives and values that they have built throughout their history. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Pakistan and India. The report contains some minor amendments which were unanimously agreed to by the delegation. I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was honoured to have the opportunity of being a member of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation which visited Pakistan and India during the period 19 July to 3 August this year. The delegation's prime purpose was to gather information about the countries it visited and observe at first hand the conditions currently prevailing, and to exchange views with as many of the people from all walks of life as possible. The delegation's other aim was to express the interest and good will of the Australian Parliament and people towards Pakistan and India. We were fortunate that the very full program provided adequate opportunities to meet and have wide ranging discussions with not only parliamentary and government officials but also representatives of industry, commerce and the professions. It was noteworthy that in both the countries visited we were made aware that Australia's increasing interest in the Asian region was welcomed.

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation was also pleased to have had the opportunity during the tour to observe at first hand some Australian aid projects. We pay tribute to the dedication and enthusiasm of the Australian personnel working on these projects. In both countries we visited we noted that there was genuine appreciation of Australia's contribution in project and food aid. I wish to place on record our appreciation and gratitude for the assistance and guidance we received from the Australian Ambassador to Pakistan, the Australian High Commissioner to India and the Australian Consul-General in Bombay, together with their staffs. The delegation benefited greatly from their experience and background advice.

During our time in Pakistan we were received by the President, General Mohammad Zia-ul-Haq, the Governors of the Sind and Punjab provinces and a number of Ministers, government officials and leading representatives from commerce and industry. The visit included the Sind, Punjab and the north-west frontier provinces. We appreciate that Pakistan is facing many problems both externally and domestically. We found that active measures are being taken to overcome them. On the domestic scene much is being done to reduce the rate of population growth, to raise the level of agricultural productivity and to develop natural resources such as minerals, natural gas and oils. Steps are also being taken to improve the balance of payments situation. We as a delegation were most impressed with what we learnt of the manner in which the Pakistan Government is handling the very difficult Afghan refugee problem. The Government and all concerned deserve the highest praise for their efforts and as much assistance with their difficult task as is reasonably possible.

Internationally, Pakistan faces a number of difficulties. Not the least of these is the continuing strained relationship with India. We believe that while some progress has been made in this regard it still needs to be done. We trust that a normalisation of relationships can be achieved given time, patience and a better mutual understanding. Strained relations between Pakistan and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which have existed for a considerable time, have been exacerbated by the invasion of Afghanistan and a spread of Russian influence in the area. We believe that this situation will not change in the short term and indeed cannot do so until the Russians withdraw and until a situation exists which will permit the return of the refugee population.

The program in India was a heavy one which involved a considerable amount of internal air travel. Nevertheless the delegation felt that despite the vastness of the country and the diversity of its people, customs and religions we were able to gain some appreciation of India's current problems and achievements, past and present. The delegation was honoured to be received by the Prime Minister, Mrs Indira Gandhi, Presiding Officers of the Union Parliament and Ministers, Government officials and a number of representatives of commerce and industry. We were impressed by the frankness and friendliness of our discussions with Ministers and their senior officials, and were particularly grateful for the opportunity of meeting the Prime Minister. During our visit we were able to gain some appreciation of India's current problems of unemployment, population growth and the movement of the population into urban areas. Nevertheless it was obvious that much had been done and was being done in an endeavour to overcome these and other problems.

The increase in food production as a result of agricultural research problems, the adoption of better farm management techniques and the development of better strains of food crops and livestock is but one example. The delegation considered that opportunities existed for Australia to expand its rural development aid projects and that consideration should be given to increasing parliamentary, scientific, technological, trade and cultural exchanges between the two countries. We had the opportunity of visiting a number of Australian aid projects which appear to be fully meeting the needs for which they were established. While there has been some question of the necessity for this type of aid this delegation strongly recommends that Australia should appreciably increase its level of aid to the development of Third World countries, such as India and Pakistan. In summary, we believe that our visit to these countries was an extremely worthwhile exercise and would hope that the recommendations listed in this report are given adequate consideration by those concerned. I commend this report.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I understand that the delegate of the permanent head will be considering the report and recommendation of the Co-ordinating Committee when they come to hand. What I can say to the honourable senator is that no decision has yet been taken. In fact there is no decision that there will be a transfer from one place to the other. I take on board and note the expressions of concern by Senator Haines for the people who reside at Magill and who are expressing opposition to a change. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a domiciliary care matter of which, unfortunately, I was not aware when I was at the Estimates Committee hearing. She nevertheless is being cared for by such organisations as the Silver Chain Nursing Association Inc. and a part time housekeeper has been called in to give as much domestic assistance as possible. He is not considered by the Department to be providing her with full time nursing care at home and therefore is not able to claim for domiciliary care. I would like some determination by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) as to whether perhaps a pro rata payment should not be made or at least considered by the Government in these cases which preclude people from becoming institutionalised. I think it provides people who could otherwise be institutionalised with a more stable and healthy life.

SPEECH.PARA: It puts great strains on the family budget, particularly when the other member of the family is perhaps undereducated or in a low income position. In this instance the wife does not need full time care in the home but she certainly does need some care. She is taken care of by the husband before he leaves for work, by the part time housekeeper when she comes in, and by the Silver Chain and other services which provide her with some company during the day. I recognise that it is difficult to single out individual cases. Nevertheless I think there is a great need in our community, unless we accept the proposition that all ill people should be hospitalised or institutionalised, for some form of relief for them.

Mr Chairman, I seek your guidance in this matter. There are other matters which I wish to raise concerning the votes for the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I seek your advice as to whether I should raise those matters now or whether the Minister would care to take them individually.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, at the moment we are dealing with all the departments in group G as one. I suggest you proceed at this stage.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Perhaps I could then raise the matter that Senator Giles raised on my behalf in regard to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. That matter concerned the provision of immediate services when they are required by Aboriginal communities. I cited the instance of the Nicholson Downs Station people who left their home on Nicholson Downs, with the exception of the pensioners as they referred to them, and set themselves up as a community on the outskirts of Halls Creek. At the time I arrived at Halls Creek-I have raised this matter on a number of occasions in the Senate-the community of some 30 or 40 people, including young children, had one canvas fly and were being provided by the Shire with a 44 gallon drum of fresh water each day. It was not until I sent an urgent telegram to the Director of the Department of Community Welfare in Western Australia that we were able to provide them with tents. I might mention once again the fact that the overnight ground temperature was down to 4 degrees at that time and I was concerned for health and welfare particularly of the children who were there.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter which arose at that same time was that of the payment of unemployment benefits to Aboriginal people who were working on stations as stockmen or station hands. I am led to believe that this is not an uncommon practice; a fairly large number of white pastoralists are in fact employing Aboriginal people as stockmen and stock hands. They are not being paid; it is not costing the stations any money. They provide them with accommodation but, quite frankly, from some of the accommodation I have seen, if a health inspector were to inspect it, they would not be allowed to live in it. But the matter still remains that there appears to be a large number of people who are being employed and who are not being paid but are in receipt of unemployment benefits. I raised this matter in relation to the Nicholson Downs Station, but it is not a unique circumstance. Officers of the Department, not those present when the estimates were being examined but other officers I have spoken to, have confirmed that it is not an unusual circumstance.

I have raised in this chamber the question of whether in fact the Government will institute an inquiry into this matter. I think it should be a relatively easy one to undertake. It is simply a case of establishing whether Aboriginal people who are working as stockmen or stock hands are actually receiving unemployment benefits. If this is so, surely the questions that have to be answered by the station owner are: What is he doing and how long has he been ripping off the Australian taxpayer? As I said, the provision of accommodation on stations is not generally of a very high standard. I think the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs would agree with me. He has seen, for instance, while the community was still there, the accommodation provided on such places as Gordon Downs which was an absolute disgrace. It is heartening to know that the members of the community have now been moved to a place where they find they can relate to the land and can provide their community with the necessary back-up system. But that is not an ideal situation even yet, and it will take some time before it is. However, the question that was raised on my behalf by Senator Giles at the Estimates Committee hearing still remains as to whether an estimation has ever been done by the Department of Social Security or, indeed, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs of how rife the practice is of employing people and not paying them wages but requesting that they receive unemployment benefits.

From that springs another problem, and that is the tendency on the part of white station owners to retain the unemployment benefit cheques and the sickness benefit cheques and to hold them at the store in payment of goods that may at some future time be received. The Minister would be aware that a large number of complaints have certainly been received by me and, I presume by his Department also, that the books never quite balance. The white station owners have been heard to say that the Aboriginals just do not understand the amounts of money that they have spent on such things as transistor radios and tape recorders. Nevertheless, the fact remains that complaints have been lodged, as I am sure they have been lodged with the Department on any number of occasions, and a proper answer has never been given by the Minister either in this chamber or at the Estimates committee hearings. Those were the questions that I asked Senator Giles to raise on my behalf. The response I got was a no-answer answer in that it did not pay attention to my suggestion that a large number of white station owners were claiming unemployment benefits while they were employing station hands.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up several points raised by Senator Coleman in relation to Aboriginal matters. I am aware of the situation regarding the Nicholson Downs community and some of the difficulties it faces. It has a slightly more difficult problem than the problem facing the Gordon Downs community. For reasons which Senator Coleman understands, it is not so clear cut. We would not want to see a community left with inadequate resources. Senator Coleman talked about one canvas fly. One of the roles that Mr Sheridan, my area officer, can play in that region is to make sure-I am certain we have-that with the wet now upon us that kind of situation does not exist.
—It did at that time, for a month before I actually visited the area.

—That is quite awkward. I am aware too that in relation to the Nicholson Downs community there was some time involved in getting requests from the community to the area officer. I hope we have overcome that problem. The substantive matters raised by Senator Coleman relate to two matters, I think. —Insisting that they receive unemployment benefits.

—Right. The difficulty we face in this matter is that we have no complaints we can investigate. We need some assistance. If there are complaints I would like to learn of them in enough detail so that we can move in and act upon them. In the Kimberley either Mr Feldman or Mr Sheridan, may two area officers who look after the region, would be looking for any information. We certainly would undertake to investigate any instances-there is no worry about this-and to make known to my colleague, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), any instance which we would investigate. Like the honourable senator, we think that practice would be illegal and quite improper. I must say to Senator Coleman that while it is an ex parte matter, while I cannot hear of an instance which I can investigate and in which we can be fair to both sides, I do not know how to answer her in any satisfactory way. I appeal to her for some assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter of accounts at stores is a recurring problem. It seems that those communities whose stores operate best are those communities in which the stores do not give or take credit. The communities that have a strong rule of cash on the knocker are the ones that do well and in which this kind of discord is held to a minimum. It is pointed out, of course, that with the capacity to use the 13-week period of retrospective eligibility, that is not seen as presenting a great problem at present.

—I want to pursue that matter. Can the Minister say what absolute numbers are involved in that? I seem to remember an assertion being made when the program was first announced that a certain number of people in the millions would be eligible for health cards. I would like just to check those figures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we were last dealing with the Appropriation Bills in Committee last Thursday Senator Coates raised another matter. Perhaps I should come back to that when I have dealt with the inquiry he has raised now. The latest advice I have from my Department, which takes us through to 6 November, is that there have been 118,511 claims for health cards. Of course, that does not mean that 118,511 individuals have health cards because a good number of those applications relate to the heads of families and hence cover the members of a family and not merely the individual who has applied for and received the card. Of the estimated three million people who are covered by the new health arrangements, about two million are existing holders of pensioner health benefit cards or are dependants of those card holders who are automatically covered by their existing cards. Of course, they have not been subjected to any change under the new system. They have continued to receive the cover which they had according to the cards which they have held for some time. Of the remaining one million or so people estimated to be eligible for the new health care cards, approximately half are registered unemployment and special beneficiaries or their dependants. Once again, those people do not have to apply for cards; they receive them automatically when they are issued by my Department every two weeks.
—Are they included in the 5.4 per cent?

—I am not relating to those percentage figures; the honourable senator will have to ping pong the ball back to this side. I am talking about the estimated cover of around three million people which was referred to by the Government. About half a million of those non-pensioner health benefit card holders are people who automatically get cover through the system because they are unemployment or special beneficiaries. The estimate-I emphasise that it has to be an estimate because it relates to the number of people who might be within the income limits that are prescribed-is that 200,000 or so individuals or heads of low income earning and migrant families might be able to apply for cards. We cannot put a precise figure on that but that is the Department's estimate. The actual number of cards issued, 118,000, is therefore a quite healthy figure in that it indicates that a quite high proportion of those people who are entitled have actually applied and received cards. About 60 per cent of those who qualify solely as low income earners or as migrants are thought to have applied. As I said before, that has to be an estimate. Of course there is still room for concern about the fact that that leaves about 40 per cent of that number not covered. I would simply refer again to the point made by my colleague Senator Peter Baume a few minutes ago, that those people are entitled to make retrospective claims and they do have a full 13 weeks in which to lodge claims after seeking treatment before their entitlement to a refund for the service performed lapses. There is that additional safeguard for them. To give one further point of detail, the number of low income claims is 104,408 and the number of immigrant claims is 14,103. I repeat that that is at 6 November 1981. Presumably there would have been some applications since that time.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week Senator Coates raised the question of overseas students and referred to the fact that a number of circulars had gone out with respect to the eligibility of overseas students for health care. I have sought information from the Department on the matters he has raised. Initial instructions covering overseas students were sent to the State offices on 28 August. The new scheme applied from 1 September. Those instructions were amended on 30 September when the Department of Health advised that scholarship holders would be eligible for a card if the scholarship did not make specific provision for health costs. Detailed instructions incorporating that amendment were sent to all States on 21 November, the date referred to by Senator Coates last Thursday. On 29 October the Department of Health advised that it had been notified by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau and by the Department of Education that the health costs of dependants of sponsored students would not be covered by those authorities after 2 November 1981. The Department of Social Security State offices were then notified that subject to the residence, dependence and income tests such persons would be eligible for the health care card. I can understand that under those circumstances there would be some room for misunderstanding and confusion and therefore I have instructed my Department to prepare a statement specifically on the question of the entitlement of overseas students. I will table that in the Senate this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that during this debate we can range across any of these three departments. It is rather odd to see three Ministers tied down at the one time. I wonder how Senator Peter Baume is going to seek advice from his advisers when he is seated in the middle of the chamber.

—Senator Georges, you are at liberty to range across the three departments but because we are in Committee and you have unlimited calls I suggest you might like to consider restricting your remarks to the individual Ministers, one at a time. That is a matter for you.

—That is what I intend to do. I will deal first with the Department of Health. I refer to page 27 of the written replies provided to Estimates Committee G. The Committee sought an up-to-date position on the recovery of nursing home benefits incorrectly paid by the Commonwealth on behalf of patients who were subsequently found to be insured. The reply refers to the present situation in each State. In relation to New South Wales, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: An amount of $1.2m has been identified at this stage.
It goes on to say that only $16,000 has been recovered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it this is the Auditor-General's report?

—That is the question I intend to raise. I am on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and I have not seen this matter raised by the Auditor-General, although I would have thought that it would have been raised. The reply then indicates that in Victoria an amount of $835,353 has been identified and that recovery action is proceeding. An amount of $138,369 has been recoverd to date. In Queensland, checking has been completed for all funds. An amount of $1,017,083 has been identified and $204,122 has been recovered. In South Australia overpayments of $1.9m have been identified and $529,134 has been received. In relation to Western Australia, the reply states:

SPEECH.PARA: Identification and verification of insured nursing home patients is proceeding although some delays have been encountered. Amounts recovered to date total $47,371 with further amounts identified as $69,086.
Apparently we are still in the process of discovering the real position in Western Australia. In regard to Tasmania, it states:
The audit in this State has been completed. A total amount of $287,488 has been identified . . . of which $24,108 has been recovered.

Those answers to questions asked by senators on the Committee reveal a rather serious situation. As I have said, these matters may have been reported on by the Auditor-General but to date I have not seen any report on payments being incorrectly made. We now find that the rate of recovery of those substantial sums of money has not been very good at all. Why is that the case? I also want to know whether or not the Australian Federal Police have withdrawn from the area of collecting such sums. If so, why? If the Australian Federal Police have withdrawn from the area of collecting such overpayments, by way of summons or by any other means, who is doing this? Is there a problem because the Department of Health has not established any process for recovering debts? These overpayments are in fact debts which have to be recovered. These are not small amounts; they are substantial amounts. I take it that it is a continuing problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Perhaps the Minister can explain how the problem has been brought to an end. I leave it at that. There is a problem, as is shown by the answers to the questions; the amount is considerable and the recovery rate is poor. Why is it poor? What processes are being used and are those processes of recovery so poor because we no longer use the Australian Federal Police to assist in that recovery.

—I understand that the situation to which Senator Georges referred quite correctly was one that arose because of an incorrect procedure which was being followed by the proprietors of some nursing homes. That procedure has now been corrected. I am not saying that from time to time individual cases will not arise in which errors are discovered. But there was a widespread practice whereby the proprietors of nursing homes were claiming on the Commonwealth when they should have been claiming on funds in respect of certain patients. That matter has been brought to light. The procedures have been straightened out. That is why I have said that it is not a continuing problem. What is a problem is the process of checking and finding the extent of overpayments that were made. This is an ongoing process. The recovery of moneys is still going on. It is not a question requiring police intervention or court action at this stage. It is a question which has been taken up with proprietors and the funds. In fact, quite a large operation has been going on and is continuing, as Senator Georges pointed out, to recover the overpayments that were made. Claims are not being made any more because people have come to understand the correct procedure for sending accounts to the funds or to the Commonwealth. The Australian Federal Police are not involved. Unless something exceptional happens they would not have a role to play.

—I understand that. I leave to one side the matter of the Federal Police. It is now a matter between the nursing home proprietor and the Department. Who finally is responsible in this situation? I take it that there would be a responsibility upon the nursing home and that in the end, all other things having failed, the money would need to be recovered from the proprietor of the nursing home. Is that the situation?

—I understand the matter has been approached by negotiation with all the people involved, that the money is recoverable from the proprietors of the nursing homes. Of course, since 1 September the situation does not arise. It is not a fund problem any more. The Commonwealth now pays nursing home benifits. It was a problem that was limited in time. It has an end point. The recovery of the incorrect payments is being negotiated now with the proprietors-I take it that is Senator Georges's question-and with the patients.
—I understand the patient does not come into it.
—It is between the funds and the proprietors and the Commonwealth.

—A few minutes ago Senator Colston raised a matter that he raised during Question Time last Thursday concerning whether the recovery action for overpayments was suspended during one form of appeal and not during another. Although I made inquiries at the time I do not have a complete answer for him. However, it does appear from indications that I have from two States that there is in fact a stay of recovery action during the Social Security Appeals Tribunal appeal and not during the Administrative Appeals Tribunal appeal. I must say that the immediate logic of that distinction escapes me. I will examine the matter that the honorable senator raised to see whether there are consistent answers from all States. I will have to advise the Chamber at a later time of the full position, the rationale and what attitude the Government takes to that matter.

—I rise to obtain information from Senator Baume, who represents the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar). I refer to an article in the Sunday Telegraph of 1 November about the mothers of Down's syndrome children. I intervene because this matter seems to be inconclusive. I am fully aware, as my deputy leader, Senator Grimes, has pointed out, that certain treatment cannot be taken unless it has been supervised and we know what its repercussions might be. This matter concerns women who have taken their children to West Germany for treatment and who want such treatment used in this country. Mr MacKellar, the Minister for Health, has said that information on this treatment is inadequate and therefore we have to be careful. The spokesperson for the mothers of the Down's syndrome children refuted the Minister's statement and said that all of the evidence that the Minister needed had been supplied. Therefore I simply compress the requests into two questions. Firstly, what information is lacking on the West German treatment that is necessary before the Minister can approve of its use in Australia? The Minister may have good reason for taking this action. Secondly, what about the catch-22 situation in which these women and their children are involved? Apparently the Commonwealth Department of Health will not approve any Medibank reimbursement for the cost of two visits a year to West Germany. Perhaps the Minister can also indicate to me what the medical research world can offer in lieu of the alleged German cure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Mulvihill is concerned that the children be treated with safety and efficacy. The very brief answer is that on the basis of information that is available at this time we are not able to say that the treatment is effective or safe. We have assisting the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee, which has certain roles to play. We have the National Biological Standards Laboratory, which has certain roles to play. We have the Minister and the Department which have to make a judgment as to the safety and the efficacy of the treatment. The information that is available to date indicates that the Siccacell products containing Lyophilised foetal or placental animal cells for use in the treatment of Down's syndrome should not be approved for importation or distribution in Australia. This is a very awkward situation. A number of products available around the world, particularly for cancer cures, simply do not work. The honourable senator will remember what Mr Brych did to people. I can make available to the honourable senator some of the information we have.

SPEECH.PARA: In brief, we have sought, and not been able to obtain, appropriate documentation as to safety. We require that information before we can certify, as we are required to do, that the treatment should be introduced. We require some information that it works. We cannot get that information. This then leaves mothers of Down's syndrome children in a very difficult position. They would like to try anything, but if the treatment does not seem to be safe and if we do not know that it works the Department of Health can in honesty do nothing else but withhold permission at present. What the Department does say is that if some proof can be made available which by trial demonstrates the efficacy of the treatment, and if the same kind of safety information can be supplied as is required for any other medicine that can be used for injection, that would be a different picture. But at present we cannot get that information. It is solely on that basis that permission is being refused. I think that really explains why there has been this impasse. I would be grateful if the honourable senator could make that known to the mothers who are concerned.

—In considering the estimates of the Department of Health I raise a matter which I raised in the Estimates committee hearings, namely, the hiring of computer consultants at a cost of some $250,000. SPEECH.PARA: The Toxic Shock Syndrome was first reported from the United States in 1978, and its close association with Staphylococcal infection and tampon use during menstruation was recognised in 1980.

While tampon use rather than the tampons themselves appears to be the predisposing factor in women, it is difficult to find any common pattern of use among the Australian cases, nor have there been any obvious changes in hygiene or in use patterns among the general population over the past decade. The document read as follows-
QUESTIONS ARISING DURING ESTIMATES DEBATE-SENATOR MULVIHILL

On Thursday, 12 November, during the Senate debate on Estimates Committee G, Senator Mulvihill tabled two letters published in the 'National Dog' concerning an imported greyhound 'Rugby' which died 13 days after its release from quarantine at Wallgrove animal quarantine station.

The first letter was a letter of complaint from the owner of the animal about quarantine and the second, a letter signed by Mr Doyle, Assistant Director-General of the Animal Quarantine Branch of the Department of Health, following detailed investigations of all aspects of the matter by that Department.
Senator Mulvihill sought assurances that everything was done for the dog during its period of quarantine.

The facts emanating from the extensive Departmental investigation in this matter are set out in detail in Mr Doyle's letter which appeared in full at pages 2163-2164 of Hansard of 12 November 1981. However, the salient features are as follows:
Records at the quarantine station show that the animal entered quarantine on 24 January 1981 weighing 26 kilos and was released on 24 April 1981 weighing 28 kilos-a gain of two kilos.

While in quarantine the dog suffered diarrhoea on three occasions. On each occasion the animal was given routine treatment and the condition was rectified within 2-3 days. This is a common complaint for imported dogs who are subjected to heavy stress following the lengthy plane flight and the severe change in climatic conditions.
The owner visited the animal twice during the quarantine period and discussed the dog's condition and diet with the kennelman. She registered no complaint.

The dog was released to the owner in good condition and was, in fact, too boisterous for her to handle. He was loaded into Mrs Schelling's transport by the kennelman. A statement was signed by the owner stating that the dog was received in good condition. Again, no complaint was lodged and the staff were thanked for their efforts.

Veterinary reports and a pathology profile of the animal obtained from the veterinarian who treated the dog following its release from quarantine indicate that the dog's symptoms prior to its death were not inconsistent with the clinical patterns of acute parvovirus diseases. This view is shared almost unanimously by State, Commonwealth and private veterinarians who have examined the case.

Senator Mulvihill can be assured that all steps were taken to care for the animal during quarantine. The case was thorougly investigated following receipt of Mrs Schelling's initial letter of complaint on 8 May. In the light of this investigation there is no suggestion of negligence by the staff of the animal quarantine station at Wallgrove.

The important feature in this case is that the animal, in fact, gained weight, some two kilos, during his period in quarantine and was released in a fit, indeed boisterous, condition. Attention is also drawn to the fact that experts advise that acute parvovirus was widespread in Australia at the time and that large numbers of dogs were affected and many died throughout the country. The quarantine station was in fact closed to visitors for a period during Rugby's time at the station to prevent the entry of the disease. Measures taken in this regard appear to have been successful.

The facilities at the Wallgrove station are by far the most up to date in Australia and have been constructed in line with the most modern concepts of disease security and animal welfare. Since its opening 744 cats and dogs have been imported through the facility with only two fatalities-an outstanding record in a facility of this kind. The quality of care provided at the Station is illustrated by the fact that one animal, an Afghan hound which has a long coat, recently won a show within two days of release after nine months quarantine at the Station.
