I am advised that the standards require that wound dressings be sterile; that bacteria were first isolated from dressings manufactured by someone called Jayer Exports Ltd and included organisms which can cause gangrene and septicaemia-I suppose clostridium welchii organisms. The nature and levels suggested gross contamination, possibly from faecal sources and a very poor standard of hygiene in the factory. Recalls at the consumer level were made. I am aware of the concern expressed to Senator Coates by his constituents. I have a constituent who has a continuing need for dressings. He has discovered that it is very difficult to obtain supplies. Dressings from two other Indian companies were also found to be non-sterile and were recalled.

SPEECH.PARA: Bandages are not required to be sterile. However, the bandages from Jayer were also found to be contaminated with the same types of bacteria as were found in the wound dressings. Testing has been extended to other manufacturers in India and other countries. So far, unacceptable contamination has been detected in wound dressings and bandages from other companies in India, Taiwan and Thailand. Some products from some companies in England, West Germany, Taiwan and China did not yield any potentially harmful organisms.

The point is that in regard to dressings, which are required to be sterile, a testing procedure is employed which in fact has picked up some of these contaminations and has led to product recall taking place. I can certainly refer to the Minister the question whether further measures are needed, whether this episode reveals the need for additional changes to the procedures now followed. However, what emerges is that because of the testing that has been done through the National Biological Standards Laboratory it has been possible to pick up these levels of contamination and we do have a recall system which permits products to be removed from shops. Probably the honorary senator, as I am is receiving representations from people who are now finding it difficult to obtain these products. I will certainly convey to the Minister the honourable senator's concern that there may be a need for a further mechanism in this regard and will await his response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is to a large extent a labelling problem, not just one of people finding difficulty in getting goods. They are also concerned about their own self-treatment.
—I will pass on the honourable senator's specific suggestion also.

—It is not just a matter of sterile dressings or of goods that one knows must be sterile. For instance, just straightforward products for everyday use, such as lint or cotton wool balls, are not required to be sterile. Someone who wants to bathe an eye or a wound would not buy them as sterile products, but they ought to be labelled correctly and a higher standard should be required in respect of them.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on my feet, I ask the Minister to confirm a matter on which Senator Chaney said he would present a report later in the week. I refer to health cards for overseas students. Can I have an assurance that the Minister, the Australian Development Assistance Bureau and any other department that is involved or needs to be involved will be able to make a full contribution to that report so that everybody will know what is going on? One of the problems with the health cards for overseas students was that the total coverage involved various departments. ADAB did not necessarily know what the Department of Social Security was doing, and the Department of Health did not necessarily know. There was a total breakdown of communication. I hope the report that Senator Chaney promised will have been agreed to by all the departments and instrumentalities involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said by way of interjection that I will pass on to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) the other specific matters raised by Senator Coates. It is my understanding that following a meeting on 21 October a set of proposed guidelines on this question of overseas students was circulated to all the departments.
—I think it has changed again.
—I take on board the point made by Senator Coates. I will make that known to Senator Chaney, which is all I can really do.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the proposed expenditure for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs be passed without requests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to page 11 of the written replies for Estimates Committee G. I direct the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to the last paragraph, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: However, all health authorities agree that the disease is unlikely to be eradicated in the areas where it is now prevalent until there is improvement in the living standards and conditions of the Aboriginal people, which may take considerable time . . .

The question I raise in this important area which refers to the eyesight of Aboriginal people and others is this: How, after all this time, do we still come to the conclusion that nothing can reasonably be achieved until the living conditions and standards of the Aboriginal people are raised? We established the Department of Aboriginal Affairs some years ago. I think we have expended over $100m every year. This year the appropriation was raised to $160m or a figure close to that amount. It is necessary for the Minister to explain just why there has not been substantial progress in this area. I wonder whether he can point out to the Committee just which are the areas of greatest problem. We have had some problems with the trachoma program. I would like to be assured by the Minister that the problems that were faced in Queensland in particular have been overcome and that the circumstances leading to stop and start resignations of important people in the program have been reconciled. I hope the Minister can understand how there can be concern in this chamber about the fact that the impression now is that in spite of the application of expertise and money we are very far from solving the problem of Aboriginal morbidity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Page 11 of the document to which Senator Georges referred went on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the disease is unlikely to be eradicated in the areas where it is now prevalent until there is improvement in the living standards and conditions of the Aboriginal people, which may take considerable time to achieve.

What it does not say is that the social and health status is in fact improving. It has gone from disastrously bad to very bad, but it is improving. Take any measure we care to name. A large number of housing units have been completed; more are needed. Take the provision of clean water or power. In the Central Desert, for example, most of the communities I visit-from Amata to Warburton-now have a power generator and water. That means the people can get washing machines in. Some of them want washing machines, some do not. Washing machines mean that the women have a chance to get the kids' clothes clean. A whole series of things are interdependent. The need is enormous, and even the steady provision of resources will take some time to pick up the backlog. The population is increasing. The Aboriginal population growth rate is high. In spite of the high death rate the Aboriginal population is the fastest growing segment of Australian society. This is not to underestimate the enormity of the need and the fact that we need to proceed as rapidly as we can.

We have announced a $50m program designed to try to help the very kinds of things Senator Georges was talking about-water supplies and sewerage-but even in some communities we find that there is another job in terms of social education. We find sewerage systems which have been destroyed through vandalism. All right, that is part of the learning process we have to go through. We might be two steps forward and one step back. I think Senator Coleman, who has been to places like Balgo, will agree that much of the housing that has been provided there may not have been appropriate, but certainly it is a sad sight to see housing at Balgo at present and to realise the important need, under the trachoma program, for housing with elevated, ventilated, separated beds, if I may mention the catch phrase used by the trachoma team. We are confident that we can continue to make progress. We certainly do not underestimate the problem. It is not made any easier by the fact that clean water is one of the big issues. There are some parts of Australia where that simply is at a premium. It is very difficult to find clean water. Of course Aboriginal communities are quite often seeking to move out into the new areas, some of which are quite marginal. We are encouraging that where it seems appropriate and where that is their own desire. Queensland has a lesser trachoma problem; it has more rain and more water. Professor Hollows, for example, made it clear that it is the red heart where the trachoma problem is most acute.

TALK.START.PARA: —It requires more attention then.

—In fact we are trying to devote a lot of the Aboriginal public health improvement program to those areas if we can to provide water and sewerage. The trachoma program is a program of the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists. I understand that that College has recently appointed or is about to appoint an officer of well-known work in one of the Aboriginal medical services to assist it as a research officer or co-ordinator for three months to develop the next phase of the program which the trachoma team within the College of Ophthalmologists might want to promote. That seems to be proceeding uneventfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not normally like to ask questions in the Committee stage because I think that is the sort of thing we do in Estimates committees; we come in here to discuss matters. There are a couple of comments I want to make in the broad general area of Aboriginal affairs. Perhaps the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), rather than answering specific questions, might like to make just a general comment. I would like to look at four basic areas. The first one is employment. In the Estimates committees hearings concerning the various departments with which I was involved we asked how many Aboriginal people were involved in government enterprises or in actual straight-out government employment. I was able to get those figures only in relation to those areas in which I was particularly involved. I wonder whether the Minister would like to comment on, firstly, the actual numbers involved and, secondly those people who are receiving training of the apprenticeship type or skilled trade training. I am not looking for specific numbers but just a general comment on whether we have had any development in the last 12 months and that sort of thing.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area I would like to look at is the broad area of education, or what one should perhaps call schooling in this case. Can we have a broad picture of the development in the secondary education field of those students who are receiving Aboriginal secondary grants? Again, I am not looking for numbers but just growth. Can we have the numbers of students who have been assisted to go on to tertiary education, whether it be at technical and further education colleges, at university or at any other sort of training institution? I think the comment I would like in this area is on whether the field is growing at present. The third area on which I would like the Minister to comment-I realise there are some problems in this area-relates to what I call the Ford committee which investigated training 12 months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Martin Ford's committee.

—Good. I need not go on with that. Can we have some indication of the findings? I know it is not the practice of the Government to release interdepartmental committee information. I think there might be a general picture that the Minister can give us.

SPEECH.PARA: The last general area on which I would like the Minister to comment-I am prompted by his reply just given-is the outstation movement and the sort of training going on there. I have always been concerned, as the Minister knows, to make sure that Aboriginal young people are given the alternative of either staying in the community, whether it be an outstation community or an Aboriginal community, or going into the regional town to work there. I think we want to make sure that Aboriginal young people are equipped with the skills to make that sort of choice. In my view they do not want to be forced into the situation where, because their elders have chosen for them to live in an outstation movement, they are not able to move away at a later stage. I am just looking to see whether the Minister has some comment to make on this general area of training in the community and at the outstations. The Minister might recall that I had some contribution to make a few years ago-I think he knows of that-when I made a suggestion about having visiting trainers and so on do this. Can I have a broad picture in those four areas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Senator Robertson asked a question about employment in government enterprises. I have a table showing staffing within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I believe the table was part of the explanatory notes or it emerged during the Estimates Committee stage. Anyhow, I have a table showing the number of officers, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I can table that document for the Committee's consideration. That is only a little of the picture.
—It is only one department?
—It is only part of our Department. Tabulations are available, which we can get for the honourable senator, showing other departments in the Public Service.
—Can they be obtained for the Committee, not tonight but at a later stage?

—They can be obtained without any trouble. In relation to our interest, the honourable senator may even discover that fewer Aboriginals are shown under the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. That is very easily explained because Aboriginal Hostels Ltd is now comprised of 93 per cent Aboriginal people.
—Drawn from the Department.

—Many of them have come from the Department. The Aboriginal Development Commission, which has been in operation for only 18 months now, has, I think, a staff comprising two-thirds Aboriginals and the number is increasing. What happened was that a number of my departmental officers went to the Commission on temporary attachment, and recruitment is picking up many Aboriginals. Again, some of them are coming from management positions in the Department. For example, I just mention that Mr Neville Perkins has recently become general manager of Aboriginal Hostels to replace a non-Aboriginal, Mr Roy Schuler. In the Aboriginal Development Commission we now have Colin Bourke, an Aboriginal, as general manager; we have Mr Charles Perkins as the chairman, and all the directors are Aboriginals. The land councils, many of the 800 or so organisations-I am not sure of the number-which, of course, we fund, have almost all Aboriginal employees. In addition, the National Aboriginal Conference has almost all Aboriginals on its secretariat.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the growth in the number of children in secondary school, I think the introduction of Aboriginal secondary grants coincided with an enormous increase in the numbers of Aboriginal children attending secondary school. I must say to Senator Robertson that the retention rate seems to be passable-not too bad-up to year 10 and to be very poor between year 10 and year 12. That is a problem we have to pick up at present. We are aware of it. We are trying to find ways of filling that gap. In 1971 the census revealed that nearly one-quarter of all Aboriginals not then attending school had never received any schooling. In 1981 we can say that more than 16,000 Aboriginal children are attending secondary schools. The figure in 1967 was, we think, about 2,500. It is now 16,000 children. If we look at the figures for Aboriginals in tertiary education-I think Senator Robertson asked for that figure-we see that 138 Aboriginals are at university under the Aboriginal Study Grants Scheme; 184 are undertaking teacher training; 681 are undertaking other tertiary studies; and 229 are completing technical studies. In the last decade 130 Aboriginals have graduated from tertiary institutions with Abstudy assistance, 125 of them since 1974.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are teacher training institutions regarded as tertiary in that sense?

—Yes, they are. There are a number of graduates. We are no longer waiting for the first Aboriginal lawyer. Now the fifth or sixth lawyer is graduating. Of course, what those people choose to do with their careers is up to them.
—There are a number of lawyers.

—There are a number of lawyers. Senator Robertson will recall that the Ford committee was established by the ministerial council, the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council. It visited all but two States. It received no responses from the Ministers in two States-I think one Labor and one non-Labor State. It concentrated mainly on remote communities in matters of training. It presented its report to the Ministers some months ago. I understand that consultations are now taking place between officers to work out ways in which the Ford report recommendations can be examined and whether they can be implemented.
—Will that be put down?

—Can I come back on that? I am not sure what my obligations are to other Ministers. It certainly will be raised at the next meeting of the Aboriginal Affairs Ministers to be held in, I think, February in Perth. It will be raised again then. In terms of the outstation movement there is a real dilemma. Senator Robertson knows this. It is the dilemma he actually highlighted about the trade-off people make for the quarantine they get from alcohol, community violence and other things they may find unacceptable and the greater difficulty they face in getting for their children some of the negotiable skills they may require to give them a wider choice. Some of the communities I visited had teachers aids going out from those communities to try to incorporate the children in the outstations in the teaching programs. I think Senator Robertson has put his finger on a problem which remains really largely unresolved-that is, how one ensures that children do not miss out on the chance to pick up the skills they may need if they wish to choose a different kind of lifestyle for themselves 10 or 15 years down the track.
—There may be something in Ford about that.

—There may be not only something in Ford; we would welcome any inputs. If Senator Robertson has any ideas we would be interested to hear them. We are constantly trying to respond to Aboriginal initiatives on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in the response to the question by Senator Ryan on page 71 of the written replies to Estimates Committee G, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: How many officers above class 7 (in the Department) are Aboriginal Women?

I am not surprised to find that there are only 13 non-Aboriginal women above clerk class 7, nor am I terribly surprised to find there is only one Aboriginal woman in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs above clerk class 7. I wonder now whether the Senate could be provided with the information relating to all Aboriginal employees in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, particularly in relation to female Aboriginals. As we already have the information for those above clerk class 7, perhaps we could have the information for those in grades below that.

I want to speak for a moment about Aboriginal hostels. In one of the suburbs of Perth there is a hostel known as the Elizabeth Hanson Memorial Hostel for Retired Aboriginals. It is a very small hostel; it is a home that has been taken over by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and presumably it is funded through the Department as a hostel for retired Aboriginals. It is a rather pleasant place to go because only a small number of Aboriginals live there, but the situation has developed in recent times where it has been required to take in people who are not necessarily retired Aboriginals. For instance, on a recent occasion a lass came down from the north of Western Australia to study at the Western Australian Institute of Technology and was unable to find suitable accommodation. Whilst accommodation was found for her through the guild, they had neglected to tell her prospective landlady that she was an Aboriginal. When she turned up to take advantage of the accommodation she was politely told that the accommodation had been let. Because she had nowhere else to go, for a few nights she was housed in the Elizabeth Hanson Memorial Hostel. This situation creates a problem. There does not appear to be anywhere in Perth a hostel for those people who wish to undertake studies or to take up employment on a transient basis or for a short time until they can find alternative accommodation.

The other rather sad situation is the reluctance of some hospitals to accept alcoholic Aboriginals, even where it is obvious that, in addition to their alcoholism, they are aged. Recently the same hostel found itself in a rather nasty position because it has no live-in staff. In fact, its entire staff number two, both of whom have their own homes to attend to and work at the hostel on a weekly basis. They were contacted by the police in the middle of the night when one of these elderly Aboriginals at the hostel passed away. I do not know what the answer is to that problem. I am more concerned with younger people having to take up accommodation in a hostel which is obviously designed for retired Aboriginals. I imagine it could be an extremely delicate situation for them suddenly to find themselves surrounded by elderly people, and in a strange city as well.

While I am on my feet I would like to raise the matter of the community which I understand is being moved very shortly to Violet Valley in the Kimberley area of Western Australia. I have spoken about this on a previous occasion. A matter has been brought to my attention which causes me some concern. I understand that the property is being handed over about now by a white leaseholder, or there is some arrangement by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs that it will take over the lease. I understand also that a surety figure in the order of $19,000 is to be forfeited in the event that the station property is not kept in a particular condition, that is, if it is not kept habitable and if the outsheds are not maintained with reasonable care. I have not been there so the matters I am raising at the moment are hearsay. It may be necessary for confirmation to be sought. I understand that the upkeep and maintenance of the accommodation have been sadly neglected. It means that the Aboriginal community will be going to the Violet Valley property already behind the 8-ball because they will not be able to work the property and be self-sufficient in the immediate future. They will have to endeavour not to maintain the accommodation but to repair it. There is also the problem of the road going into Violet Valley, which I understand is in a shocking condition. They will not be able to maintain contact with the community at Turkey Creek, which would not be a desirable situation as most of the Violet Valley people have been in fairly close contact with those at Turkey Creek for quite some time.

I was very interested to hear the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) say in relation to the trachoma-glaucoma program that it is necessary for the people to have proper accommodation and raised bedding. That brings me back once again to the matter I have raised in the chamber before in relation to Queenie McKenzie at Turkey Creek. I would be very interested to know whether there is any progress in the matter of Queenie McKenzie, who wishes only to have a proper house. As she has said to me: 'I do not want to live in a humpy all my life. I want to sleep in a house, in a proper bed.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking the last matter first, I have recently made further representations to the Minister for Lands, Mr Wordsworth, in relation to Queenie McKenzie's problem. I understand there is some movement on that matter. I am rather hopeful that the extra area of land across the creek at Turkey Creek may become available. I have recently written a follow-up letter to the Minister seeking his assistance. In relation to Violet Valley, I think that is probably a matter which the Aboriginal Development Commission has taken on. The honourable senator has raised the important point that in their purchases they would want to take on places which are not run down to start with. Of course, one of the difficulties is that the properties for sale are not always the best properties to be found. I think they are aware of that particular danger. The honourable senator is aware of that.
—It is the property they want; I acknowledge that.

—This is an Aboriginal Development Commission matter, and I will bring to its attention the concerns of the honourable senator. In relation to Perth, I recall early this year opening Allawah, a new hostel-one of the 109 or 110 run by Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, out in Guildford. We know there are hostels in Perth. I agree that it is highly undesirable that a person should be placed in one inappropriately. I am not aware of the particular home the honourable senator mentioned. We will look into it and see whether it is a third party hostel or whether it is associated with Aboriginal Hostels in some way. We will see whether we have an interest and whether we should take any action in relation to the matters the honourable senator raised tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to staffing, the question we answered at page 71 of the written replies was the question asked. We can now go ahead without too much trouble and obtain for the honourable senator the other part of the information. I am aware of the Aboriginal woman who is a clerk class 9.

TALK.START.PARA: —So am I.

—She is a very good officer. Of course the honourable senator is also aware who she is. It will not help anyone to over-promote people and it will not help anyone to hold people back. We find with the clerks at less senior levels that a number of people are coming through. It is a question of making sure that in their own interests they do not get landed in jobs before they are ready for them. Certainly we will obtain that information for the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: I might add to the answer I gave to Senator Robertson that through Department of Aboriginal Affairs programs training this year will be given to about five and a half thousand people. That relates to the report by Martin Ford. We will fund the States to provide training for about 2,400 people this year. Through organisations by way of direct grants in aid there will be training for 2,800 people, and the Special Works Project Scheme will provide training for about 300 people. So some training is going on. I might also mention in relation to outstation education that we are providing $125,000 to assist in the Northern Territory to try to make some impact upon the problem to which Senator Robertson referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just raise one more problem that came up at the time when the Elizabeth Hanson matter was raised with me, namely the employment of Aboriginal people under the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals scheme. I think that most people on this side of the chamber have a trainee under that program. I was rather disturbed in my conversation with the people who are actually running the Elizabeth Hanson hostel to find that, as I explained earlier today, only two people do all of the cooking and cleaning and make sure that people get off to the doctors and that sort of thing. I spoke to the employment officer and I was very pleased to find that in fact there is the possibility of placement of NESA trainees at these types of hostels at which they could get some training in the very basic operations of a small hostel, which is to be desired, as against the much larger ones. I was rather surprised to find that the people at the hostel were not aware that in fact they could apply for a trainee under the NESA scheme. I wonder just how widely the Department is advertising the fact or alerting areas inside the Department as to the use of those trainees in its own organisations?

—As Senator Coleman knows, under the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals scheme we try to provide training which will be employment-oriented so that people can leave us and move into jobs. I am now starting my third NESA trainee. It has been very good to see trainees develop skills and take up employment. Hostels use the scheme extensively. Therefore it is known in this area. We will certainly look into the matter. However, I think there may be a little difficulty in making sure that some of the third party hostels are spreading the word.
—Can you tell me what you mean by a third party hostel?

—Aboriginal Hostels Ltd runs a number of hostels itself. Sometimes it provides facilities for other people to run the hostels. Aboriginal Hostels is a most effective organisation. It is one of the few organisations which will close hostels that are not being used and use the resource it frees. It will sell the property and open another one. It is really very good in this respect. A third party arrangement is one way of extending its scope. I will have to take that up. I might say that I have another table which shows that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in toto we have 66 Aboriginal men and 84 Aboriginal women employed. I can table this document which shows a breakdown State by State but it still does not answer completely the question that the honourable senator asked and on which we will get some more information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise several matters under the heading of Aboriginal Affairs. The first concerns a matter about which I wrote to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) some time ago and in respect of which I have not yet received an answer. I wrote to the Minister supporting a request from the Murray Bridge District Council that continued funding be made available to the Woma program at a farm which caters for alcoholics on the Karoonda Road some five or six miles from Murray Bridge. My understanding is that some concern has been expressed by the Aboriginals in Murray Bridge that the intention is to have a rehabilitation home in the town of Murray Bridge. The people who run this rehabilitation farm are most concerned because such a move would make their job much more difficult. The people they deal with would have easy access to the cause of their problem. I would now like to know whether the Minister can give me an answer.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot develop tonight the other matter which I wish to raise because I am not yet in receipt of the South Australian Hansard. I am given to understand over the telephone that a most unwarranted attack was made on me last week by Mr Lewis, the member for Mallee in the State House, because of my actions in trying to assist the Ralkon Agricultural Co. at Meningie. As soon as I can get a copy of the Hansard I will refer to this matter in the Parliament. I will be saying a few things about Mr Lewis which he might not appreciate. He will get a great shock when I mention them. He is just a babe in the woods. He is a newcomer to the problem. He has been in the Parliament for about only two years. He is one of those Johnny-come-latelys who is an instant expert. I just warn the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that I will be saying a few things about this matter in the future because it comes within his ambit. If Mr Lewis is prepared to repeat in the public arena some of the statements he has made about the manager of Ralkon I am afraid he will need a very big bank account. However, I will leave that to a later date. What I am especially interested in tonight is whether the Minister has an answer for me about the Woma program, particularly as it applies to Murray Bridge in South Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to get back into the Ralkon argument. Like Senator McLaren, I will be interested to see what Mr Lewis may have said. Senator McLaren might recall that he accompanied me to Point Macleay when I visited that area early this year. I think that Mr Lewis is the local member for that area.
—Yes.
—I do not know what appears in the State Hansard. I will be as interested as Senator McLaren is to see what Mr Lewis said.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Woma program, Senator McLaren might be interested to know that today I signed a response to him. I had actually waited to sign a response to the local government body in Murray Bridge. I have enclosed a copy of that response in my letter to the honourable senator. The letter should be with the honourable senator now. What we have said is that, as Senator McLaren knows, there has been a review of Woma programs generally throughout South Australia. A number of recommendations have been made which are being discussed. What we are seeking now is a response from each Woma program about the recommendations. There is yet another stage for us then; that is to look at those responses and to determine exactly how we should proceed-whether to continue our support of these programs as they are or as modified, or whether we continue with the State secretariat as it is or in a modified form. A number of things have come out of the review. The honourable senator may recall that Mr Miller, who is assisting me in the chamber, as the regional director in South Australia actually helped get that review under way.

There are two separate questions at Murray Bridge. The first concerns the Woma program itself. The second concerns the particular question of the farm as a tool which that program uses. I have made no decisions at all. However, I see the questions as separable. How the Woma program itself should be run is an important question. I might say that the review expressed some concerns about some improvements that could be made in the operation of the program. That is all right. If there are some improvements to be made we will look at those recommendations on their merits.

The question of the farm is one that will have to be considered on its own merits in terms of the costs involved in respect to maintenance and the kind of benefit that it will yield. I assure the honourable senator that no decisions have been made. My mind is not made up one way or the other on the whole matter. I am going to wait until we have responses from different Woma groups and then look at the whole thing in toto.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pending a decision being made, will sufficient funds be available for the farm to continue? I am concerned that the establishment might be closed down. Once an establishment is closed down it is very difficult for it to be reopened.
—Very briefly, I am advised that the money we have allocated is enough to maintain the programs while the review is being completed. It is not intended to cut off funding in the meantime.

—Can the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) inform me as to what, if any, Federal Government input, by way of discussion, firstly, there has been with the Victorian department responsible for Aboriginal affairs or the Victorian Government in relation to a land rights claim by the Aboriginal people on the Framlingham reserve just out of Warrnambool? Have these people made some formal or informal request to take over the forest which was part of the original Aboriginal reserve? That reserve was established perhaps 120 to 130 years ago and later was excised to the Forests Commission of Victoria. I am just wondering whether there has been any discussion with the Federal Department of Aboriginal Affairs by anybody in relation to that claim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

I seem to recall that we tried to lend our good offices to the local people in negotiations with the Victorian Government. I think that was some time ago. TALK.START.PARA: —The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the vote in respect of the Department of Social Security be now passed without requests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the fact that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is not here, I raise initially the present problems in the Department of Social Security and the industrial dispute involving the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, whose members are working in the Department of Social Security. I think the Committee should know that staff ceilings, which are at the bottom of these problems, have been a problem in the Department since 1976. The hardline resistance of the Government to increases-what are considered satisfactory increases by members of the ACOA and other employees of the Department-in staffing have been met with what now have become desperate devices to gain the Government's attention and the Government's understanding about what has been happening in various sections of the Department. At all times the ACOA, acting on behalf of Social Security officers, has tried to meet with the Minister for Social Security, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Public Service Board to explain the seriousness of the staffing situation in terms of services, efficiency and morale in the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: Some staffing improvements were made recognising that under the present Government unemployment benefit payments had risen by 50 per cent. This is a high figure but the staffing has changed very little in the last six years. The other staffing improvements which occurred came as a result of a move which coincided with the appointment of Mr Lanigan as Director-General of Social Services, when the policing of pensioners and beneficiaries became of greater concern than giving those people fast and accurate service. Increases in staffing were made in the Department to carry out Mr Lanigan's philosophy that the Department should restrict expenditure rather than support those in need in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is Mr Lanigan up to now?

—Mr Lanigan is not there any more. He has resigned and is in a very comfortable legal practice. I seek from the Minister an explanation of why he and the Government are so intractable in dealing with the staff of the Department and why the whole matter raises the Minister's ire, as it did in Question Time today. Officers of that Department have, over the years, maintained a high standard in the community and have a very good industrial relations record. In fact until the last couple of years industrial action in the Department was almost unheard of. The reputation of the Department of Social Security over the years has depended upon the efficiency and the good sense of these officers who are at the moment in dispute with the Minister and the Government. It seems to me that the Government and the Minister are giving every indication of being even less interested in what staff are needed to do the work required in the regional and other offices than in the people whom the Department is supposed to support.

SPEECH.PARA: The aim of the Social Services Act is to help those in need in this community and any dispute of this type must inevitably affect those in need. At the moment staff members of the Department are prepared to lose wages in order to bring home the principle that the provision of services to the poorest and the most dependent social service recipients in this community is a serious matter. The officers have been in dispute with the Government, the Minister and the senior echelons of the Department for over 12 months. The Minister and his top advisers are losing no pay, but the staff are in fact losing pay and they are showing more responsibility about delays and stress in the Department. As a result of this they are up for all the punitive actions that the Minister, the Government, the Public Service Board and others choose to take in this situation.

A joint Department of Social Security and ACOA committee examined the staffing setup in May 1980. In July 1981 it concluded that a minimum of 500 additional staff members were needed in Victoria alone for relief staffing. Departmental and Government inaction initially, and now the intransigent attitude of the Government, have led to the present situation. At Question Time today I brought to the Minister's attention the particularly provocative action of his senior administrators-I noted that in his answer he disclaimed responsibility for anything like this-in deliberately standing down people who were writing counter cheques; that is, senior administrators were demanding that officers stop writing hardship cheques and work on overpayments. When the officers refused to do this they were stood down. This is a pretty rough way of stopping essential services to the disadvantaged in order to impose departmental authority. At the time, Senator Chaney asked me for details about specific cases. I am not sure whether he did this because he did not believe I had such information or whether he was using the old ministerial procedure in this place of trying to deflect criticism on an important point without giving that criticism any consideration. Therefore, I take this fortuitous opportunity of the consideration of the Appropriation Bills to give the details. I give them in the hope that the Minister will not order further punitive action because these people had the temerity to report to their union what had occurred in their Social Security offices.

In the Redfern office of the Department of Social Security on 12 November, one David Cowell was preparing cheques in the unemployment and sickness benefits section. Although he was a pensions officer, he had been asked to do this work. He was ordered to stop writing the cheques and to work on overpayments. He refused and was stood down. In the same Redfern office Peter Law, Therese Traves, Glen Dwyer and Norm Haskell were all stood down because they refused to stop issuing hardship cheques and to work on overpayments. In the Camperdown office on 9 November, one Steven Bolt was stopped doing hardship payments and told to do overpayments. He refused and was stood down. At the Liverpool office, Ken Bernoth was working on the computer run for unemployment and sickness benefits cheques. He was told to do overpayments. He refused and he was stood down. In the Belmore office a pensions officer, Vincent Senat, was preparing an emergency cheque when he was told to do overpayments. He refused and was stood down. In the Marrickville office the manager was stood down for refusing to stop his staff working on hardship payments, stating that he believed their work was too important to stop and that he would rather be stood down himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most depressed areas in Sydney.

—The Redfern, Camperdown and Marrickville offices are, as Senator Sibraa said, in areas of high unemployment and high migrant populations. They are areas where there are large numbers of disadvantaged people. In these offices people who were working on hardship cheques were asked to stop that work. When they refused to stop writing those cheques and to go on to the less urgent problem of overpayments, they were stood down. All this has occurred after a dispute which has lasted 12 months, yet at Question Time today the Minister had the temerity to complain bitterly. He talked about how disgusted he was with the activities of the officers in his Department who work in regional offices where they have to deal with the problems of the most disadvantaged people in this community. I know that the Minister is very disturbed at the situation. I know that he is disturbed at having to take the pigheaded attitude that he does take in this area. I know he is disturbed that in New South Wales some 29 offices have been closed, that 15 are providing collection services only and that 274 people have been stood down. But by his attitude at Question Time today he shows very little concern for those officers who in past years have worked very hard for the disadvantaged people in this community, who have worked under considerable difficulties without ever having taken industrial action and who only now after 12 months of trying to get some satisfactory response from the Department and the Minister are put in the desperate situation in which they have to take industrial action.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister and his Department quite callously concentrate on the area of unemployment and sickness benefits and deliberately do not put pressure on those officers in the pension area because they know that is politically undesirable. This is not proper industrial relations. This is cold, calculated, cynical, political action by the Minister and by those whom the Minister has immediately underneath him in the Department. I think it is a disgrace. I think it is a great problem that we have disputes like this in the Department of Social Security. But the people who are taking industrial action now are doing it only out of desperation. It is about time the Minister and the Government stopped their combative attitude, stopped their confrontationist approach and talked with the officers in the Department for the benefit of the disadvantaged people and indeed for the benefit of us all. Unless the social services legislation is administered in a reasonable and humane way we will not be acting in a civilised manner, but then I suppose this Government is not very interested in acting in a civilised manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally I would have waited for other honourable senators from the Opposition side and any other honourable senators who were interested in speaking on the estimates for the Department of Social Security before intervening in the debate but because it is proposed that the Committee should report progress shortly I thought I should make some very brief response to the points made in Committee by Senator Grimes. The first thing is that once again there appears to have been some exaggeration in what has been put down about the effects of this strike on the operations of my Department. The most recent advice I have is that within the State of New South Wales, where there are 58 regional offices, 39 are not affected at all. There is some effect in 19 of the offices, with four either being closed or with a mere trickle of work and 15 generally processing work but with some delays.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event I express my regret that the spokesman for the Opposition on social security matters should so uncritically support the position of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, which is a position not being supported by the majority of those people who work within the Department of Social Security, who are getting on with the job of serving the public, who are earning their pay and who have my admiration for that. I also appear to have made very little impact on Senator Grimes by directing his attention to some of the statements of the union with respect to the way in which it suggests that unionists should go about their work and the obstructionist tactics that it suggests they should adopt. What Senator Grimes seems to be saying to the Committee is that these Social Security officers are entitled to choose what work they shall do and to ignore the instructions of their senior officers when they are directed to work. Clearly that is a situation which is totally incompatible with the management of the Department and were--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is clearly not what I am saying.

—The examples cited by Senator Grimes related to people who apparently had been carrying on what they saw as the priority jobs of the office and were not prepared to take instructions and do the jobs which they were directed to do. In the event that Senator Grimes ever becomes a Minister I suggest that he will not find it compatible with his duties as a Minister of the Crown to have a situation in which the Department for which he is responsible does such work as is determined by individual officers at their discretion on their view as to what the client of the Department might require. I indicated at Question Time that any particular complaints that were raised would be examined, and of course they will be examined. But on the face of the complaints which have been made, we have a succession of complaints that officers have chosen to do the work which they see as priority and not to do the work that they are told to do by the Department. This whole dispute is being pursued in a manner which is aimed at trying to hide what is at the basis of it. The fact of the matter is that the union has raised areas of concern in three discrete ways. It has suggested that there are difficulties in the Department with respect to accommodation, that there are difficulties in the Department with respect to training and that there are difficulties in the Department with respect to staff ceilings. As I have previously indicated in this chamber, in all of those three areas the administration of the Department-the senior management of the Department-with the support of the Government has been assiduous in tackling those problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at the area of accommodation-I visited offices which clearly were deficient in that respect-the Government made an allocation of over $2m within the last few months to ease some of the pressure points. Details have been given to the union and have been made public about the work which is being done to improve the training situation within the Department. The present position is that there is a substantial additional allocation for most of the rest of this financial year which will enable additional training to be undertaken. But with respect to the most critical aspect of the dispute, the question of the staff ceiling, the fact remains that this Department has had a very significant growth in its staff numbers under this Government, a growth which is not paralleled in any other department-going from the vicinity of 9,000 in 1976 to nearly 12,400 at the moment when one takes into account the temporary cover as well as the permanent ceiling of the Department.

It simply is not compatible with the facts to have the sort of action which is currently being taken in the Department particularly when one looks at the fact that for 12 months we have had bans being imposed by officers who believe they have the right to determine what work they will do, that the Department has patiently worked to improve the conditions which have been a matter of complaint, that bans have been lifted in all States except New South Wales and Victoria and that the union has shown that it is determined to maintain to itself the right to determine what work will be done and demands the right to determine what the staffing level of the Department will be. Those demands are simply not compatible with the proper management of the Public Service.

I give the clearest possible indication to this Committee that it is the Government's concern to see that the Department of Social Security is adequately trained and that it is adequately housed. I do not believe that anyone who examines the facts in this matter can in any sense justify the action of the union. Whatever the facts I do not believe the action of the union would be justified. When one looks at the reality of the position it certainly is not.

I referred this morning to the fact that this tiny band of people in the Department who see themselves as entitled to call the shots are actively suggesting to members of the Department that they should engage in behaviour which is obstructionist, which will delay the work of the Department and which will prevent people from getting benefits. Their main purpose in doing this is to try to avoid stand downs yet achieve the effect of not getting work done, of maintaining those bans. That is not acceptable, it is not reasonable, it is not fair and it is not just and it will not be acceded to by this Department or by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially I merely wish to reply to the remarks of Senator Chaney who tonight has taken the same tack as he took today. I reiterate for the Senate the actual history of this matter. There has been concern and difficulties over staff ceilings in the Department of Social Security for a long time. The present dispute has been going on for much longer than 12 months. Senator Chaney spoke about the problems I would have were I Minister for Social Security. The simple difference between Senator Chaney and me is that, if I were Minister for Social Security, I would do what people normally do when there is an industrial dispute; I would sit down and talk to the people involved in the dispute. That is what Senator Chaney has consistently refused to do. That is the first matter. He has consistently refused to sit down and talk to the union.

SPEECH.PARA: The second objection I have-it is the objection that Senator Chaney continually skates around when he speaks on this matter-concerns the selective application of the Government's actions in this area. What has happened is that under instruction from the senior officers of the Department and, therefore, the Minister-Senator Chaney takes up the tack that the previous Minister used by saying it was the responsibility of the senior officers rather than himself-discriminatory and selective actions have been taken. Those people who are involved in writing out cheques for people who need emergency assistance have been asked, while doing that work, to do other work which in anybody's view is less urgent and in which in anybody's view would take them away from the proper work of the Department in assisting those in dire and immediate need. When these officers, including some managers, refuse to do that they are stood down. This is not done in other areas of the Department. It is a selective application of the stand-down procedures. It is a political act by the senior officers of the Department under the instructions of the Minister.

The Minister is wrong if he thinks that he can get up in this place, as he did at Question Time today, and say: 'It is not me doing it. It is the Director-General and senior officers who are charged under the Social Services Act to do this'. If he thinks he can get away from the responsibility, as the Minister who preceded him in this job used to think, he is wrong. We will not allow him to do it. We will continue to point out the inconsistencies of his actions. If he wishes to have those on unemployment and sickness benefits in this community penalised by his heartless actions and the heartless actions of those who are responsible to him we will not stop pointing this out; we will continue to point it out to the community. We will persist in bringing this matter up in this Parliament when the Parliament is sitting and outside the Parliament when the Parliament is not sitting.

I do not take any joy in seeing industrial disputes in the Department of Social Security. I point out that until a couple of years ago, until this Government came to power, industrial disputes in this Department were unheard of because the officers of the Department are conscientious and decent people. They are not going to be trodden on and stood over by the likes of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) who is determined to create industrial disputes for his own political purposes. He is taking the line of his master, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He will not succeed in the long run. He is not succeeding in the short run. We will continue to bring this matter up. His good and conscientious officers are no more impressed by his rhetoric than anybody else around the place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Australian Labor Party has made it quite clear that it accepts the right of the trade union movement to determine staffing levels and what work shall be done in government departments. I have made it clear that neither I nor the Government accepts that. I make it quite clear also that on the inquiries I have made the Department of Social Security denies there has been any selective application of the sort indicated by Senator Grimes. I make it quite clear also that in pointing out what is a practical fact as well as a statutory fact the management of the Department is in the hands of the Director-General and his officers. If facts and allegations are raised they are not matters on which I can give a personal response immediately. That is a simple matter of fact. I accept with great pleasure the responsibility for the actions of my officers. I am happy to continue the debate at a later time.

The Government has reconsidered its position in the light of the action taken by the Senate to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill and the Australian National University Bill to delete the limited tuition fees provisions, and also to reject the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill which dealt only with fees.

The Senate has disagreed with the House in two important respects. It has not been prepared to endorse the provisions of the Bill passed by the House which authorise the limited reintroduction of student fees for selected second degree students, and it has also taken a contrary view to the Government as to the Senate's powers in respect of this legislation. During the debate in this chamber the Government argued that the Senate did not have the power to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, but it did not dispute the right of the Senate to request amendments to this legislation. The Senate, however, decided that it did have the power to make amendments and proceeded accordingly.

The Government regarded the Senate's action as contravening section 53 of the Constitution and it invited the House to set aside the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill in the form received from the Senate. The House has done so.

The Government is now proposing a new measure which will provide for the program of grants to the States without the fees provisions to which the Senate objected. If the Senate approves this Bill, we will then introduce a separate Bill to amend the first Bill to restore the fees provisions.

In the case of the Australian National University, the House has accepted the Bill as received from the Senate, and it has also approved amendments to restore the fees provisions. The Senate will be asked to approve these amendments. The Government is not proposing to take any action for the present about the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill which the Senate rejected.

The Government has had to keep in mind that the principal purpose of the legislation is to appropriate funds totalling $1,725m for the universities, colleges of advanced education and TAFE institutions in the States and the Northern Territory for 1982 and further appropriations for some areas for 1983 and 1984 also. Provision has also to be made for cost adjustments in respect of the program for the 1979-81 triennium. Many institutions will be short of funds by late December unless this legislation is passed in sufficient time for the appropriate instalments of approximately $300m to be made available from the Commonwealth through the State Treasuries to the institutions. Their position will be made worse if further instalments of about $100m cannot be made in late January.

The grants reflect the Government's approval of the financial recommendations put forward by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in respect of State and Northern Territory institutions and in accordance with the guidelines announced by me on 4 June 1981. On 24 September I tabled Volume 2 of the Commission's Report which responded to the guidelines.

The Bill is in the form of the Bill amended by the Senate except for some minor differences to overcome technical defects in the amendments adopted by the Senate to remove the new tuition fees provisions.

In putting forward this Bill without the tuition fee provisions, the Government has recognised the urgent need to ensure that funds will be available to tertiary institutions in the States to proceed with their approved programs. Some funds are yet to be allocated for 1983 and 1984 and will be included in subsequent annual amendments.

However, the Government will continue to press for the limited re-introduction of tuition fees for universities and colleges of advanced education. The Government accepts that fees should not be charged to first degree or diploma students, but it believes that students entering second diploma or degree courses or higher degree courses should pay tuition fees. These fees would be applied to a minority of students and would represent a small contribution to the cost of operating the institutions.

The inclusion of this tuition fees provision in a States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill as a condition to the grants for recurrent expenditure for universities and colleges of advanced education is the only mechanism open to the Commonwealth by which it can take legislative action. There is absolutely no question of the Government attempting to tack-on some extraneous matter to an Appropriation Bill. The Commonwealth has the sole responsibility for financing the universities and colleges of advanced education and has the authority to make a decision about fees and to attach that as a condition to its grants. It has been the practice since the grants for the 1974 academic year for the States Grants legislation for tertiary institutions to include a condition requiring the States to ensure that the universities, colleges of advanced education and TAFE colleges do not charge tuition fees. The Government has sought to continue that provision, except for second and higher degree students.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) (a) That a Standing Committee of the Senate, to be known as the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, be appointed to report, in respect of the clauses of Bills introduced into the Senate, and in respect of Acts of the Parliament, whether such Bills or Acts, by express words or otherwise-
(i) trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;
(ii) make rights, liberties and obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers or non-reviewable administrative decisions; or
(iii) inappropriately delegate legislative power or insufficiently subject its exercise to parliamentary scrutiny.

(b) That the Committee, for the purpose of reporting upon the clauses of a Bill when the Bill has been introduced into the Senate, may consider any proposed law or other document or information available to it, notwithstanding that such proposed law, document or information has not been presented to the Senate.

(2) (a) That the Committee consist of six Senators, three being members of the Government to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and three being Senators who are not members of the Government, to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or by any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators.

(b) That the nominations of the Opposition or any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators shall be determined by agreement between the Opposition and any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators, and, in the absence of agreement duly notified to the President, the question as to the representation on the Committee shall be determined by the Senate.
(3) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That three members of the Committee be necessary to constitute a meeting of the Committee for the exercise of its powers.

(8) That the Committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.
(9) That the Committee be empowered to appoint with the approval of the President counsel to advise the Committee.
(10) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

I thank the Senate for the opportunity of bringing on this matter before the end of the session. The motion I have moved provides for a standing committee of the Senate to be known as the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I have proceeded with this course because, after three years and a great deal of consideration, I believe that the time for this idea has come and it is desirable that the Senate should start to exercise this type of scrutiny. It will be recalled by honourable senators that two reports were presented to the Senate in November 1978, one on the scrutiny of Bills and the other on the delegation of parliamentary authority. The reports dealt with a connected subject, and the recommendations and proposals contained in them were for the establishment of a joint committee of both Houses to carry out the scrutiny that was found to be necessary.

It has proved impossible to have such a joint committee because the Government has not been prepared to accept that application. The course I am proposing I believe is the one which it is now desirable for the Senate to take. It is desirable because the Senate's review role is not adequately performed, yet that is the major and primary function which the Senate has been carrying out for many years. The initiative for this idea came from the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney. In his pre-ministerial days he put forward the idea, which was taken up by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of which he was then a member. He may not have quite the same enthusiasm for the idea these days, but to him must go the credit for it. The purpose of the committee and the criteria for its establishment are set out in the motion. As a summary I will read the words I used when tabling the two reports of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. On 23 November 1978 I said:

In assessing the need for such a committee we noted that many Bills come before the Parliament which contain provisions that: Significantly interfere with personal rights and liberties; delegate powers which, arguably, should not be delegated at all; delegate powers to affect rights, liberties and obligations without providing an opportunity for the exercise of those powers to be reviewed either by the Parliament itself or by an independent body; or delegate powers to impose obligations without any clearly defined guidance as to who is to impose them, upon whom and in which circumstances.

We commented in our scrutiny of Bills report that such provisions may well be the product of conscious and deliberate Government decision and, as a result, may have been extensively debated. But very often these provisions are not necessarily central to the policy objectives of the Government, do not as a result gain especial prominence, and in the rush of legislation tend to slip through the Parliament without full debate or any debate at all. There is, as a consequence, a need to maintain a watching brief in respect of these types of provisions. Whilst the Parliament can never hope to foresee and provide for every contingency, we believe that it can do a good deal to implement procedures to supervise the administrative decision-making process and to strengthen the position of the individual. The establishment of the joint committee on scrutiny of Bills would do just that.

Now that that possibility has escaped us for the present time, I believe that a Senate committee would do a task which would be nearly as good. A year later, on 22 November 1979, the Government made a response and rejected the proposal. It was rejected on most extraordinary grounds, and on arguments which were criticised heavily in the debate by honourable senators, including Senator Hamer and myself. Amongst other things, it was suggested that somehow this would cause delay in the passage of legislation. It was also suggested that this work was already done by the Cabinet and legislation committee, by back bench committees, and so forth, including the law and government committee of our parties, of which I was then deputy chairman. This was not so. We know that many of these proposals have gone through. It is important not to raise that argument, because it was unsound then, but to point out that since 1979 there has been no change in the situation; there is not a difference. In fact, this will be demonstrated by the examples I propose to place into the record of the Senate. The examples show that these provisions are going through without proper debate taking place in the Senate. The public response to the Committee's recommendations, in 1978 and 1979 was excellent, both in the Press and elsewhere. When the response of the Government came down Professor Gordon Reid, who I think everyone will agree is one of the eminent authorities on parliamentary affairs and the responsibility of government to the Parliament, had this to say at the Commonwealth Conference of Delegated Legislation Committees in September 1980:

I believe that the Senate should now defy the Executive Government's negative reaction to the two reports of its Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee and establish its own committee of scrutiny over new delegated powers in legislation and matters of official discretions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Those were the words of Professor Gordon Reid, the Deputy Vice-Chancellor of the University of Western Australia. I say to Senator Chaney that he is an eminent authority. I believe that his words were correct. I must confess that I have followed what I believe is his good advice in introducing this motion. I point out to the Senate that there is a slight difference in the proposal I make from the proposal for a joint committee. The suggestion that there might be delay in the passage of legislation is taken away because the provision originally in the report was that if a Bill was to go through in less than four days then the Government would have to move for the suspension of Standing Orders. The major argument for this proposal is that the vital role of scrutiny is not adequately performed at the present time. That this is a review which needs to be made was evidenced by the Age on 16 December 1978 when it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee would have no power to impede or disallow legislation, but its ability to scrutinise and publicise could have a persuasive influence of constraint on overweening government. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Many examples are provided in the document, which I believe has been distributed to honourable senators who will be able to study them. I am not saying, of course, that all or even the majority of those provisions should not have been passed but the attention of the Senate and of the people should be drawn to examples of reversals of onus of proof, or requirements that people answer questions that may incriminate them, and the like. Yet those provisions often went through without any comment whatsoever in the Committee stage in this Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate, or such a committee as I propose, would need expert advice of counsel, just as does the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. Counsel could draw the attention of the committee, which would be made up of busy people, to specific provisions and it in turn could take the matter further. I wish to refer to a classic case which I have raised in the Parliament. In fact, I raised it at Question Time today. It concerns the Atomic Energy Amendment Bill of 1978. Senator Georges and I raised certain questions concerning civil liberties in regard to it. However, they were not central to the main debate in the chamber at the time and were swept aside. Now it is proposed, as the Government indicated today, to try to repair the deficiencies in that legislation. That is the vital need. The Government, and others, have argued against my proposal. During the course of the whole debate various old arguments have been brought up. The arguments that I shall mention now were considered and rejected in the Senate committee reports. I have taken the opportunity of preparing a memorandum which has been distributed to the leaders of all parties and to Senator Harradine. It incorporates purposes of the proposed committee and the answers to various questions and queries raised. To save time I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.
