The document read as follows-
MEMORANDUM TO GOVERNMENT SENATORS CONCERNING A NOTICE OF MOTION GIVEN BY SENATOR ALAN MISSEN (19.8.81) FOR CREATION OF A STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS
This is a summary statement of issues raised in debate on this proposal and makes reference to the documents which should be read to appreciate the purposes of the Motion.
DOCUMENTS

(1) The Motion is designed to implement generally the unanimous recommendations of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee Report (Parliamentary Paper No. 329/1978). (See also my tabling statement-Senate Hansard 23.11.78 page 2450 and following). Reference should also be made to the twin 'Report on Delegation of Parliamentary Authority' tabled the same day and proposing the same solution to the problem. There are necessary alterations in my Motion to accommodate a separate Senate Committee, rather than a Joint Committee, which was the favoured alternative solution of the Committee but which was rejected by the Government in its 'Response'. (See Senate Hansard 22.11.79 p. 2795 and following). The extraordinary arguments then advanced in that Response are criticized by me and by other Senators in the following pages of Hansard.
The two Senate Committee Reports are relatively short documents and require to be read to appreciate the scope and intention of the proposed new Committee.
PURPOSE OF COMMITTEE

(2) The Government is obviously unwilling to sponsor the creation of a Scrutiny Committee, which would bring both or either of the Houses into the work of regular scrutiny of the terms of proposed legislation, to ensure that Bills (a) do not interfere with personal rights and liberties, (b) provide adequate review of administrative powers and decisions, or (c) do not unduly delegate legislative powers without proper parliamentary scrutiny. In a similar way to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee (dealing with subordinate legislation), this new Committee would be advised by competent Counsel, develop a similar bipartisan approach to 'technical scrutiny' and consitute a valuable weapon for Senators in fulfilling their review role. The proposals of the Consitutional and Legal Affairs Committee were widely praised at the time the Report was presented (and since) and further investigations made by the staff of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee have revealed that, since the Reports came down, there have been many Bills where provisions appear to infringe the proposed guidelines or where the terms should at least have been drawn to the Senate's attention. Samples of this survey (or Bills passed in 1980 and 1981) will be detailed in my speech in support of the Motion.
QUESTIONS AND QUERIES
(3) A number of questions and queries have been raised. They are all dealt with in the Reports but the following are summary answers.

(a) Is this 'technical' scrutiny already adequately performed? No. Neither Parliamentary Counsel, nor Party Committees have sufficiently concentrated on the machinery provisions and many examples can be given. Existing Committees dwell mainly on major policy considerations. The Law and Government Committee, for example, deals with legal bills only and has never entered into 'civil liberty' aspects of other bills. Party committees confine themselves to bills in their allotted policy area.

(b) Should the Regulations and Ordinances Committee handle scrutiny as an additional task? No. That Committee is already fully committed with a massive agenda each week requiring extensive reading and study, nor could its Counsel be expected to absorb this further burdensome task. By imposing the burden on the same Senators (and a burden which would become demanding and tedious for them), we would threaten the continued operations of a most successful Committee of the Senate. It is worth bearing in mind that in New Zealand both bills and regulations are scrutinized by one Committee and in practice, regulations are hardly even considered by that Committee.

(c) Should the Consitutional and Legal Affairs Committee be given this additional role of scrutiny? No. The constant and often urgent demands arising from scrutiny of all sorts of bills would ensure a depletion of reports from this Committee in its 'law reform' role. Indeed it has not at present the staff nor time to handle adequately the Annual Reports sent to it. Moreover, its members have no special knowledge outside the legal reform area that would make them uniquely fitted to perform the scrutiny task for all bills.

(d) Should the scrutiny of bills be done by each Standing Committee in its area of expertise? No. The task would be performed in a ragged fashion dependent on the other business before the Committee (preparation of reports, heawring of evidence, etc). There would be great disparities in the number of bills sent to each Committee and some other Committee or person would have to determine which committee would do the scrutiny (some bills are relevant to more than one policy area). Moreover, the appointed Counsel would have to consult with up to 8 separate Committees and report to them separately. Of course, a Scrutiny Committee, which would develop some expertise and methods of operation, would not replace the need for Senators, in their individual capacity or as Standing Committee members, to watch the terms of Bills close to their particular interest. It is an additional weapon to perform tasks not adequately done at present.
PRESENT NEED

(4) For these and other reasons, the recommendation to create a separate Standing Committee for the scrutiny of bills was made. It was an idea originally of Senator Chaney's, warmly welcomed, analysed and expanded by my Standing Committee and it can greatly enhance the effective operation of our review role.

There are many suggestions made for separate Select Committees to be set up by the Senate but, of course, there are limitations on the number of such Committees that can be properly manned and staffed by the Senate. However, I believe that we should consider, as a first priority, the setting up of any Committee necessary to complement the primary work of the Senate in its review process and it is with this in mind that I press this proposal.
ALAN MISSEN 16 October 1981 Senator for Victoria

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I will just mention certain of those arguments at this stage. I have referred to the argument that this work is already performed by Cabinet and Cabinet Committees, Parliamentary counsel and Parliamentary committees. We know that that is not so. Sometimes it is done but the party committees are looking at the essential policy considerations and often miss the detailed proposals in a Bill. It is said that the proposal would delay legislation. I point out that there is in the motion no provision that could result in the delaying of legislation. The Senate, or House of Representatives, of course, can delay legislation if that is its wish. At times it should do so, but that will not happen because of the existence of this committee. It is also said: If you want this done, let the Regulations and Ordinances Committee do it; there is already a committee available. To follow that course would be unfortunate and rather burdensome. Anyone who knows the type of work that the regulations and Ordinances Committee has to do each week, the hundreds of pages that have to be looked at by its members, would realise that to add this task would be unnecessarily burdensome.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that in New Zealand, where a Statutes Revisions Committee with somewhat similar powers considers both Bills and Regulations, as Professor Keith Jackson has pointed out in an article, the examination of regulations has died away and that course is hardly ever followed. Therefore, we do not want to do anything that would damage the great record of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. We are also told: 'Let each of the standing committees do this. Let each of them be a Scrutiny of Bills committee'. We can imagine how ragged would be such a performance. Some committees would be taking evidence. Some would be busy; others would not be. The whole eight committees would have to seek from time to time the advice of the counsel and I believe that would be an impossible achievement. I repeat, there is nothing in this proposal which suggests that existing standing committees ought not to look at Bills. Their attention ought be drawn to defects but we do need a committee that is charged with that duty.

It is also suggested that the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee might well undertake the task. I know that my colleague, Senator Hamer, intends to move an amendment to the effect that for the first six months that Committee would have the responsibility of carrying out the proposed function and reporting back to the Parliament. I am aware of his proposed amendment. I merely say that although I think it will be proven that there is need for a separate committee, I would be very happy that there be a trial period such as he suggests. I certainly will support the proposed amendment and hope that other honourable senators will do likewise.

I do not think that it can be said that there are in this Parliament too many committees already, but if there are the essential tasks ought to be ones pursued. The central task of review is the one that we are not performing sufficiently. If it is said that there is not enough work for such a committee, that the committee will not be busy all of the time, I draw attention to the fact that we have committes such as the Privileges Committee which are not always busy. However, very often one has to have such committees to ensure that a responsibility is accepted for a certain task.

I believe that in this proposal we are providing a facility which is useful for both Houses of the Parliament. We cannot have a joint responsibility in such a committee but can, as senators, continue to exercise this particular power. I believe that we have to ensure that objections to Bills are drawn to the attention of the Senate. They need not be thrown out but we need to be shown, we need to be warned. We have even more need for that in Australia since in this country we do not have a Bill of rights. I am not one who presently advocates having such a Bill, but other senators do. However, because we do not have one it is all the more reason why parliamentary scrutiny is essential and should be undertaken more thoroughly. The onus is surely on us to ensure that civil liberties are protected, that Bills are not passed which damage them. We must ensure also that bipartisanship is protected and assisted in the Parliament. We know, regardless of what the public may sometimes think that most things in the Parliament are done in a bipartisan spirit. Therefore, I ask honorable senators to vote for the motion. I ask them to put their votes where their mouths have always been. We have maintained that we are proud of the record of this Senate as a house of review. Review is not adequately undertaken at present. This proposal gives us a chance to undertake review in a much more adequate fashion. For these reasons I urge that the motion be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The key to Senator Missen's motion, which I welcome, and the call which entitles it to the support of the chamber, is the emphasis throughout that the task of the proposed committee is to report to the Senate, to maintain a watching brief. It would primarily carry out a task on our behalf. It would provide a watchdog service for senators. It may alert us to its opinion that such and such a proposed law might trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, might make rights, liberties and obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers or non-reviewable administrative decisions or might inappropriately delegate legislative power or insufficiently subject its exercise to parliamentary scrunity. Having alerted us to that opinion, its warning task, its alerting task would be complete.

SPEECH.PARA: This chamber and the Parliament itself may not be convinced that the Bill, if enacted, would have the sort of impact which the committee claimed, the chamber may agree that there is some impact but not of a degree which should cause concern, or it may agree that the Bill would have a severe and detrimental impact but that some countervailing considerations persuade us as legislators that the Bill, on balance, would serve the good government of the people. But we would be doing so with open eyes. There would be proper debate as to the conflicting considerations. In other words, there ought to be no inadvertent trespassing unduly upon rights and liberties or unduly making rights, liberties and obligations dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers and so on in contravention of the criteria laid down. In the ministerial statement responding to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which recommended such a mechanism on our behalf-a response, I might say, which was delivered some 12 months after the Senate Committee made its report-only two arguments really were mounted in opposition to the proposal, and they are both contained in the sixth paragraph of that ministerial response, which I shall read. Senator Durack made the response on behalf of the Government. He stated:
. . . the present proposals amount to injecting a new element into the legislative process and one which we believe will distort, and may lengthen, the present arrangements.
That is the first argument. The second argument is:

We believe that every member of the Parliament should be concerned, when legislation is before the Parliament, with any questions of human rights and civil liberties which may arise. This proposal would tend to make this concern the responsibility of one small group only.

I understand and would imagine that Senator Chaney will adopt the same sort of argument on behalf of the Government. In other words, in two years he has had no reason to change the view of the Government, but I hope that the four counter arguments that I will put tonight may give him cause to reflect over the next couple of nights until Thursday night when the matter comes back into this chamber. To the first argument that the formation of such a committee may lengthen the present arrangements for the passage of Government legislation, or indeed any legislation, I think there are four answers. Firstly, the composition of the committee would be six senators, three of whom may constitute a quorum to enable the committee to discharge its function. It would be aided by legal counsel. It would have the ability to meet at any time, whether the Parliament is prorogued or whatever. Given the acceptance of Senator David Hamer's proposal that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs members be the first members of the Senate to constitute that committee, its composition and the mechanism I have outlined would allow the quick discharge of its responsibilities.

Secondly, as we made clear in paragraph 3.12 of the Committee report, clauses of the Bills are to be referred to the committee, not the Bills themselves. That would bring progress of the Bills through the chamber to a dead standstill. The clauses of the Bills would be referred to the committee, and that would allow contemporaneous consideration by the committee and by either chamber of the Parliament. Once again in that regard there would be no lengthening or distorting of the mechanism for getting the Bill through the Parliament. Thirdly, and of course this is related to that point, the process of scrutiny could begin before the Bill is introduced into this chamber. In other words, clause (1) (b) of the motion states:

That the Committee, for the purpose of reporting . . . when the Bill is introduced into the Senate, may consider any proposed law or other document or information available to it, notwithstanding that such proposed law, document or information has not been presented to the Senate.
In other words immediately, I imagine, upon the affirming of the motion for a second reading in the House of Representatives, the clauses could be put to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even earlier.

—Or even earlier, and we could begin working on behalf of this chamber immediately, before the matter came into the Senate. But finally, and to make it quite clear that the process of the mechanism of scrutiny proposed would not impede the legislative process should the Government desire that a piece of legislation should have a very speedy passage through the Parliament, the committee would be empowered to report in respect of Acts of the Parliament. In other words, though the principal or invariable task of the committee would be to report on clauses of Bills coming into this chamber, should the Bill pass into law before the committee has had a chance to carry out its scrutiny and then report, it may report after the event. Then, of course, the onus would be on this chamber to consider very seriously, if the matter required it, whether some amending legislation ought to be brought forward to remedy the defect which had appeared.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the first of the Executive's arguments against Senator Missen's proposal, and indeed the Senate Committee's proposal, therefore fails. There is nothing in this proposal which would delay or distort the passage of legislation through the Parliament except, of course, for such delay as would enable this chamber properly to carry out its responsibility of deliberation with informed consideration. That surely answers the second argument within that paragraph in the ministerial response. Far from lifting responsibility from the shoulders of the other 58 senators within the chamber, I believe that lawmaking by senators would become that much more onerous and far more responsible because of the benefit that the other 58 senators may have given them by reason of the fact that they would have before them a report on the Bill from the scrutiny committee insofar as it may have an impact in the areas outlined in the criteria. That means that rather than having something slip through the surveillance of this chamber because of our concentration on some primary policy objective embodied in the Bill, our attention would be drawn to where it may unduly trespass on civil rights and liberties, and our decision making would be that much more responsible for the help of the committee. Of course this does not apply only to Government legislation. The benefit which this chamber would derive from the work of such a committee would apply to any Bill before it. We in the chamber are becoming quite conscious that that embraces not only Government Bills but also Bills emanating from individual senators from other groupings-the Opposition, the Australian Democrats or the Independent senator-and individual senators within the Government ranks.

Mr President, I do not intend to elaborate on the criteria suggested in Senator Missen's motion. They are general rather than overly specific; they do not use itemised check lists. The Senate Committee felt it would be difficult in expressing criteria with a required degree of precision in a check list exhaustively to detail those matters which might indeed call for a remark by such a committee. It is better to leave general criteria rather than specific. In any case the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, constituting the interim committee of Senator David Hamer's construction, would have a chance to report to this chamber on whether the criteria, general as they are, are adequate to the task we ask of them.

I believe we are dealing here with a matter which is at the heart of our parliamentary democracy. Section 51 of the Constitution makes it clear that it is for the Parliament, subject to the Constitution, to have power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to various matters. Section 61 reposes in the Executive the responsibility of carrying out and executing those laws, but we have the responsibility of being the creative law makers of this country, those who determine the legal structure and framework within which Australians can live as free people and prosper within a mixed economy. We have to create the laws. We have to create the legal framework and structure and it must be an enhancement of our task, our responsibility, and an aid to our carrying out of what we are burdened by the Constitution to do to have available to us the report of a scrutiny committee such as is proposed. Insofar as this proposal of Senator Missen deriving from the Senate Committee enables us more honestly and adequately to discharge that responsibility, I believe it is to be commended to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter of concern relating to three departments of the Australian Government; The Department of Administrative Services, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission within the Department of National Development and Energy. The matter of concern revolves around two computers-a secondhand 4Mb IBM 3031 model 4 processor and a new IBM 3033S processor. The Pacific Computer Weekly, in the issue dated 13 November 1981, a magazine circulating among data processing and computer people in Australia, New Zealand and other Pacific countries, identified a remarkable example of government incompetency. The magazine states:

SPEECH.PARA: Second hand computer equipment being brought from IBM Australia for installation at the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Canberra will cost conservatively $190,000 more than identical equipment available on the open market for used IBM equipment.

An Australian computer broker told Australian Computer Weekly he could have supplied identical equipment to that going into the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-A 4Mb 3031 model 4 processor and two items of related equipment-to full current IBM specification, for $160,000 inclusive of installation and all other costs.

The situation apparently is that the computer to be purchased is currently installed under lease at the Atomic Energy Commission. The computer magazine has estimated, working from current IBM price figures available in the industry, that the secondhand computer available from IBM will cost slightly over $350,000-as I said, a difference of $190,000. The Atomic Energy Commission is contemplating up-grading its computer facilities to the twice as powerful 3033S processors. From a Government that never hesitates to broadcast its alleged commitment to free enterprise and the virtues of competition in the market-place, it is disturbing that both computer purchases were made without any public tenders. In both cases, the Department of Administrative Services issued certificates of inexpediency which allowed the purchases to proceed without going through any tendering process.

Two excuses may be put forward by the Government to explain its lack of consistency. The first is that the Immigration Department has an installation deadline of 1 December. However, the computer journal suggests that no approaches were made to used-computer brokers overseas or in Australia to see whether such a short deadline could be met. The second excuse might be that the Atomic Energy Commission, by having its lower grade computer sold to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, has saved itself a penalty of about $120,000 forfeited through breaking its lease. So the situation is that the Immigration Department is paying an exorbitant price so that the Atomic Energy Commission, an authority within the Department of National Development and Energy, may avoid expenses. The question remains whether all this manoeuvring will in fact save Australia money or simply boost the profits of a large multinational corporation. To conclude, I again quote from the Pacific Computer Weekly. It states:

The alternative possibility-whereby the Australian Atomic Energy Commission paid the $120,000 penalty and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs sourced a used 3031 for around $160,000, would have saved around $70,000 to achieve the same results. In fact, it would probably have saved closer to $100,000 when transportation, installation and related costs built into the broker's $160,000 but additional charges with IBM are taken into account.
So much for a government supposedly committed to cutting costs!
